description: ﻿Jane Doe went to a police station, accompanied by her children's father, to request a warrant against her girlfriend's ex-girlfriend after an incident at a night club. Doe, who identifies as lesbian, had filed a report over the phone the previous week. At the police station, the on-duty officer directed Doe to go into an office next to the waiting room to complete the report. The officer spoke to Doe inappropriately, stating that she looked too good to be her age. Upon learning of her sexual orientation, the officer made inappropriate jokes and told Doe he needed to speak to her privately in his office. The father of Doe's children tried to accompany her, but the officer did not allow him. Once in the office, the officer closed the door and pushed Doe against a wall, kissed her neck and groped her buttocks and vagina. The officer asked Doe about her “favorite sex position” and continued until another officer knocked on the door. The officer went back to his desk and allowed the other officer to open the door, telling him to come back later. Doe rushed out of the office once the door was opened.The officer told her she was at the wrong station to file the warrant. Doe traveled to another police station where she reported the incident at the nightclub as well as the officer's sexual assault. She provided Internal Affairs detectives with a written account of what happened and identified the offending officer via photo lineup, along with a DNA swab from her neck, where she had been kissed.

Guzman was the victim of a series of unwarranted stops and searches in addition to threats, racial harassment and false allegations by officers in Garfield Ridge, where he and the officers live. The first incident happened in spring 2013 when Guzman was helping his grandfather pass out fliers to promote his grandfather’s landscaping business. Officer Emily Campbell, who has a family member that owns a competing landscaping business, threatened to arrest the two men for passing out their fliers. That summer, Guzman was repeatedly asked by the officers to leave Wentworth Park, a public park in the neighborhood, and in many of these instances, searched without justification. In fall 2013, he was pulled over near South Archer Avenue and South Central Avenue by an unknown female officer who searched his vehicle without cause. Two male officers arrived later, and one of them called him a "spic." Though nothing illegal was uncovered, the officers issued Guzman a false citation for driving without headlights. In January 2014, Officer Emily Campbell pulled Guzman over near South Narragansett Avenue and 56th Street, searched him, and released him after nothing illegal was found. Guzman was pulled over two months later by unnamed officers near his own home and accused of driving a stolen vehicle, only to be released after his mother appeared at the scene with the vehicle’s title and his insurance card. Several weeks later, Guzman was again driving near his home when Officers Sautkus and Sean Campbell (Emily Campbell’s husband) pulled him over. Guzman, his passenger and the vehicle were searched – a small amount of marijuana was found on his passenger and nowhere else. The officers falsely claimed that they found marijuana in Guzman’s car and charged him with possession. His car was impounded and he was never able to retrieve it because he couldn’t afford the fees. During the arrest, Guzman’s iPhone was confiscated, never inventoried and also never returned. The possession charge against him was dismissed.

Salazar was driving when Officer Donald stopped her and asked to see her driver’s license. Salazar gave Donald her valid license, but Donald arrested Salazar and took her to a police station, where she was charged with operating a vehicle without a valid license. As a result, Salazar’s car was seized. The criminal charge against Salazar was later dismissed.

Perez was in his home in the Edgewater neighborhood when the officers, who had a search warrant for his son, entered the home with their guns drawn. They shot and killed Perez's dog, even though the dog was not attacking anyone. When Perez heard the shots, he entered the room and officers arrested him and charged him with aggravated assault. He was found not guilty at trial.

Crockett was arrested without a warrant and taken to a police station, where officers made him remove his clothing and then strip-searched him. The officers, including Crisp, Smith, Jones, Denton, Witt, Koenig and Rojas, all falsely claimed that they had observed Crockett making a drug sale. As a result, Crockett was held in jail for a month until the charges were dropped.

Blunt and Lewis were driving on South Wentworth Avenue when Officers Wedster and Pienta stopped, arrested and charged them. Blunt and Lewis were held in jail until the charges were dropped four days later.

Johnson was arrested without probable cause in connection with a narcotics search conducted at an address where he had never lived nor visited. Johnson was not connected to the narcotics found in the search Officers Carey and Kakos performed, they still brought criminal charges against him. The charges against Johnson were later dismissed at trial.

Miller was arrested in the South Shore neighborhood and taken to a police station by Officers White and Rogers. Officers at the station ordered Miller to participate in a strip search. Miller was handcuffed, placed in a head lock and kicked by Officer White. The kick broke multiple bones in Miller’s face and lacerated one of his eyes. Miller did not resist or hit the officers during this encounter. Other officers witnessed White’s abuse of Miller but none intervened. Miller was placed in a cell and pleaded to the other officers for medical attention. He was taken to a hospital after a shift change two hours later.

Gray was in a public place when Officers Hitiris and Lambe seized and arrested him without cause or warrant. The officers falsely charged Gray with criminal activity, but the charges were terminated nearly four months later.

﻿Price was in a minor car accident near the alley behind his home when Officer Rodriguez arrived. Price exited his vehicle and began filming the encounter on his phone. Rodriguez told Price to put his hands on the hood of his car. Price complied, and continued to record the encounter on his phone. Rodriguez punched Price in the face, pulled him backward and slammed him to the ground. While Price was lying facedown on the ground, Rodriguez kneeled on his back, grabbed his head and slammed Price’s forehead against the pavement. Price began screaming for help as Rodriguez tried to take his phone. A few minutes later, several other officers arrived and began kicking Price as he lay on the ground. Officer Barak pepper sprayed Price, and Officer Kirschner used a Taser on Price twice. The officers handcuffed Price and continued kicking him and stomping on his head. They mocked Price for screaming for help during the incident, and took his phone. Price was charged with obstructing arrest, driving on an invalid driver’s license and other charges. About seven months later, the charge of obstructing arrest was dismissed. As a result of the incident, Price suffered from black eyes, bruises, cuts and swelling.

Garcia and Aderman were at their home when officers wrongfully entered with guns drawn, pointing their weapons at them. Once they learned they searched the wrong apartment, the officers left without an apology.

﻿Montano was driving his car when Officer Wallace pulled him over, handcuffed him and falsely accused him of possessing illegal drugs. After searching Montano's car, Wallace arrested him, even though he did not find any illegal drugs in the vehicle. On the way to the police station, Montano told Wallace he was diabetic and needed to get his insulin out of his car. Montano continued to request his insulin after they arrived at the station and told Wallace he was getting sick. Wallace moved Montano to a different room and handcuffed him to a pole. Two hours later, Montano began screaming for help and told two officers, including Wallace, that he was having a “diabetic attack.” Though the officers ignored Montano and tried to continue processing him, a supervisor entered the room and told the officers to call an ambulance. Montano was then taken to the hospital and diagnosed with diabetic ketoacidosis. He stayed in the intensive care unit until the following afternoon. Montano was charged with possession of cannabis, but the charge was terminated two months later.

Redmond was robbed and called the police to report the incident. When Officers Rivera, Haidari and Pivaral arrived, they ran his name through their system and falsely told Redmond there was a warrant for his arrest. The officers took Redmond to a police station, where he provided his identification and fingerprints. Neither his photo nor his fingerprints matched those on any warrant. Haidari prepared a complaint for a search warrant for Redmond, alleging that Redmond had been involved in the delivery of a controlled substance. Redmond was arrested and spent several weeks in jail.
Gama was arrested and taken to a police station, where he was physically assaulted by Officer McNally. Gama suffered facial injuries from the attack.

Hubbard was driving in the Bronzeville neighborhood when Officer Vianna pulled him over. After exchanging a few words, Vianna handcuffed Hubbard, brought Hubbard to his car and forced Hubbard’s face to hit the side of the car. Vianna kept Hubbard in custody in Hubbard’s car for some time without responding to his requests for medical care. Vianna later issued Hubbard two traffic tickets and let him go.

﻿Tolbert Jones and his grandson Colin Craybeek live in the garden level of a three-floor apartment on Chicago’s North Side. Onzell Hale Washington lives with her son Jerome Hale and grandson Dejong Montgomery on the main floor. All of the plaintiffs heard a loud banging at the building's front door. Sergeant Dakuras and Officer Diblich broke down the door and stormed into the home with guns drawn. Jones, who is a security guard and licensed to carry a gun, put his gun on his bed out of fear of the officers. Dakuras and Diblich walked through the apartment’s main floor and garden level pointing their guns at all of the plaintiffs before finding Jones’ gun on his bed. Dakuras and Diblich took the gun and arrested Jerome Hale, seizing $400 from Montgomery and $900 from Hale. They put the gun and the money in a bag they found in a closet. Dakuras and Diblich then took Hale to a police station, where Hale was asked to provide information about drug dealers in the area. About 30 minutes after leaving the home, Dakuras and Diblich returned with guns drawn to retrieve the bag with the gun and the money. When Dakuras and Diblich asked where the gun was, Montgomery replied that Jones had taken the gun and left the house. Dakuras and Diblich grabbed Montgomery, yanked his arm, took him to their squad car and threatened to arrest him if Jones did not return and give them the gun. One of the plaintiffs called Jones, who returned and gave his gun to Dakuras and Diblich. When Jones asked how he could get his gun back, Dakuras replied, “You’re never getting your f**king gun back.” Hale was eventually released from the police station. The gun and the money were never returned.

﻿Jackson was driving on Loomis Street near 54th Street in the Back of the Yards neighborhood when Officers Doskocz and Schmid pulled him over and ordered him out of the car. Jackson provided a valid driver’s license and proof of insurance. The officers handcuffed Jackson and searched his car but did not find anything illegal. The officers told Jackson they would strip-search him, and put him in the backseat of their police car. Doskocz and Schmid pulled Jackson’s pants down and violently beat and struck him. They did not find anything illegal. The officers told Jackson to leave the area, and Jackson sought medical treatment for cuts across his face, scalp and neck, as well as a burst blood vessel in one eye.

﻿Hamilton was at a bar when he realized his phone and several other patrons’ phones had been stolen. The bar’s security called the police, and Officer Kroll and another officer arrived at the scene. They arrested Hamilton on suspicion of criminal trespass based on a complaint signed by the bar’s security personnel. Hamilton had previously sued Kroll in a civil rights claim, for which Hamilton received a settlement of $42,000 from the city. When Kroll brought Hamilton to the police station, he apparently told his fellow officers about the previous lawsuit. After the officer had gone off duty, one or more police officers used excessive force against Hamilton, injuring his face and body. Hamilton reported the abuse to a sergeant, who called the Independent Police Review Authority (IPRA). The next day, an IPRA investigator interviewed Hamilton at the station and took pictures of Hamilton’s bruising and swelling. The investigator, however, failed to make any effort to determine which officers had beaten Hamilton, claiming it was “not his job.” The criminal trespass charge against Hamilton was ultimately dismissed. Hamilton was wearing diamond earrings when arrested, which were removed once he was taken into custody. His earrings were never returned to him.

Spearman was at her North Lawndale home with her children, C.T. and D.R., when Sergeant Elizondo and several police officers broke down the door and entered her home with their guns drawn. Spearman was handcuffed, and the officers told her they had a warrant for her home. After illegally searching Spearman’s home, the officers confessed they did not have a search warrant, and broke down the door to another apartment. In that apartment they found drugs, paraphernalia and thousands of dollars in cash. Elizondo gave Spearman $1,000 in cash for “her troubles” and left.

Baines was outside his house in the East Garfield Park neighborhood when Officers Garcia and Pronek pulled up in a squad car and told him not to move and to raise his hands. Although Baines was not breaking any laws, he complied. At the same time, three individuals in a nearby car ran off. The officers found a gun near the car and arrested Baines. Baines was charged with unlawful use of a weapon and criminal trespass to a vehicle, and spent six months in jail until he was found not guilty.

Iheme, who is disabled from multiple back surgeries, was driving when he noticed a police SUV tailing him. The SUV turned on its lights and pulled him over. When Officers Palmer and O'Reilly got to the plaintiff's car, he asked what he had done wrong. The officers told the plaintiff they didn't need a reason or to explain why they'd pulled him over. Iheme told the officers of his disability, but they ignored him and aggressively pushed him against his car to handcuff him. The officers put Iheme into the police SUV and searched his car. Scared and in pain, the plaintiff asked to go to a hospital and for officers to explain why he'd been stopped and handcuffed. The officers ignored him. Thirty minutes later, the officers finished searching the plaintiff's car, finding nothing illegal. They then told the plaintiff he was free to go. Iheme again asked to be taken to a hospital, but the officers again ignored him. Later that night Iheme took himself to a hospital to get relief for his back injury, which had been aggravated by the officers' treatment.

Officers Carter and Skarupinski responded to a call about Lee’s boyfriend. When the officers arrived at Lee’s housing complex, they arrested her boyfriend and attempted to seize her car. When Lee questioned them, the officers arrested and falsely charged her with obstructing a police officer. The charge was later terminated.

﻿Laura Thompson and her son Derek Thompson were at home along with Laura Thompson’s brother and her husband, Douglas Coley, when several police officers kicked in their front door. The officers had a search warrant for crack cocaine based on allegations that Laura Thompson’s brother was selling drugs. The family dog, Tango, began barking from about six feet away from the officers, but did not approach them or growl at them. Laura Thompson assured the officers that Tango would not hurt them, to which Officer Vincent said, “He’s got to go.” Vincent shot Tango three times, and Tango ran into a nearby bedroom, injured and bleeding. The officers asked Derek Thompson about selling drugs, and Derek Thompson explained that he had a full-time job and did not sell drugs. The officers searched Derek Thompson and the home without finding any drugs or other contraband. They accused Derek Thompson of having a gun in his bedroom, but Derek Thompson denied owning a gun. Officers Coda and Guerrero arrested him and Officer Medrano approved the arrest. Derek was taken to Cook County Jail, where he stayed for more than a month before posting bond. As a result of the arrest, Derek lost his job at a company where he had worked full-time for 20 years. Because he lost his job, his home went into foreclosure. More than a year later, Derek was found not guilty of all charges. Tango died soon after the incident.
Moctezuma was riding his bike when two officers approached him and directed him to stop. The officers then searched Moctezuma’s pockets, arrested and beat him.

﻿Roberts, a supervising investigator at the Independent Police Review Authority (IPRA), was driving home around 1:30 a.m. when several police officers stopped him for a minor traffic violation. The officers approached Roberts’ car with guns drawn and ordered him to get out. One or more of the officers pushed him to the ground, and one of them said, “Don’t make me f**king shoot you.” The officers searched Roberts’ pockets and wallets, locating his IPRA ID. Officer Ellison ran back to the police car and turned off its video recording equipment. Roberts was handcuffed and began to plead with the officers to loosen the handcuffs, or use multiple pairs, because they were too tight. The officers ignored Roberts and put him in the back of a squad car, with Officer Adams asking, “What are you going to tell me next, you can’t breathe?” Roberts begged, “I’m 6’3”, 315 pounds, these handcuffs are too tight.” One of the officers replied, “That’s your fault.” The officers removed Roberts from the car and pushed him to the ground. He lost control of his bowels, and was eventually taken to a police station, where he remained locked up in soiled clothes overnight. Despite repeated requests, Roberts was never allowed to speak with a supervisor or report his injuries. At one point during the night, an unknown officer looked in Roberts’ cell, laughed at him and walked away. Roberts was eventually given tickets for multiple minor traffic violations and a charge of driving under the influence. The tickets had a box to indicate whether the incident was recorded on video. The officers did not indicate there were any videos, despite the fact that Roberts’ driving was captured on tape before it was turned off. The officers also checked the “No” box on the Alcohol Influence Report that asked if the incident was video recorded. Following a bench trial, Roberts was acquitted of the DUI charge.

﻿Haynes and a friend were standing outside when a man approached them with a gun and tried to rob them. Haynes and his friend struggled to get free, and Haynes was able to grab the man’s gun. Haynes ran toward Officers Waldbuesser and Kahn, who were in the area, and told them he had just been robbed but had managed to take the gun. Instead of looking for the robber, the officers arrested Haynes and charged him with unlawful possession of a handgun. They also detained Haynes’ friend for several minutes, but eventually allowed him to leave. Haynes spent about 30 days in jail for the false arrest before he was found not guilty during a trial 10 months later.
Spence was arrested in the Auburn Gresham neighborhood and taken to a police station for processing. There, Officer Beard physically attacked Spence, causing serious injury.

Jones was driving his car around 9:30 p.m. when he reached a police roadside checkpoint. Jones stopped his car, and during the course of the stop, Officer Visor arrested Jones on suspicion of driving under the influence of marijuana. Jones was not under the influence. Without a warrant, Visor searched Jones and his car without finding any contraband. While Visor took Jones to the police station, Jones asked to be taken to a hospital to take a drug test. Visor refused, and Jones was released from custody the following day. Jones immediately went to the hospital for a drug test, which revealed that Jones had no illegal drugs in his system. As a result of the incident, Jones’ car was towed and he had to pay to get it back. Jones had also been working as an Uber driver, and was forced to stop work due to his arrest. The DUI charge was dropped six months later.

Smith and Willis were in their first-floor apartment in the South Shore neighborhood when officers came into their residence instead of the second-floor apartment specified on the search warrant. Officers broke down the front door with a battering ram and entered the apartment with their guns drawn. They pointed their weapons at Smith and Willis' dog, threatening to shoot it. After conducting a search through the apartment and failing to uncover any contraband or evidence of criminal activity, the officers acknowledged that they were in the wrong space and left.
During an arrest, Officer Clay threw Lumpkins into a car and chipped her tooth. She was charged with resisting arrest and reckless conduct. The charges against Lumpkins were dismissed.

Roberts was at a gathering where several people got in an argument. Roberts was not involved and left. As she was leaving with a friend, she noticed several police officers outside. Three of the officers grabbed her friend and began to arrest him. Roberts continued to walk, and as she approached the street, an unknown officer quickly came up to her and struck her in the face with a hard metal object. The force of the blow led Roberts to stumble into a parked car before falling to the ground, losing consciousness. Roberts regained consciousness in an ambulance, and was taken to a hospital where she underwent treatment, testing and stayed overnight. Roberts lost a tooth and suffered a facial fracture, bruising and ongoing headaches. Because of her injuries, Roberts was unable to return to work right away and lost her job.

The Jacksons were at their home in the Roseland neighborhood when Officers Puszkiewicz, Ewing and others entered and searched the home without a warrant. The officers then seized the plaintiffs without their consent.

Officers stopped Wilson while he was walking with a group of people, including his cousin, Dominique Terry, who had an outstanding arrest warrant. During the stop, Officers Kelly and Bastien asked to see ID from Wilson and Terry. After reviewing their identification, Kelly gave Wilson's ID to Terry, but kept Terry's ID. Police then arrested Wilson for the warrant that was pending for Terry. Wilson told officers multiple times that he was not Terry and that they had the wrong person, but the officers ignored him. Wilson was taken to the 5th District and held on the warrant pending for Terry. The next day a judge confirmed Wilson was not Terry and he was released.

﻿Spearman was with friends at a park in the Logan Square neighborhood when officers approached his group with their guns drawn. The officers commanded the group to get on the ground. The officers then began pushing, grabbing and battering Spearman. One officer grabbed Spearman’s arm and twisted it, spraining his wrist and shoulder. Spearman was arrested and taken to a police station, where he requested medical attention. His request was denied. Spearman sought treatment after his release from custody, and claims that he continues to feel pain to his shoulder and wrist.

﻿Officers Johnson and Mielcarz parked their police car in front of Garfeed's home in the Humboldt Park neighborhood with the intent to arrest Garfeed. They took Garfeed into custody in the front yard, and when Garfeed asked the reason for the arrest, he was told “You know what you did.” Garfeed was handcuffed and pulled backward, falling and hitting the back of his head on the building’s front gate. When he regained consciousness, Johnson and Mielcarz were trying to lift him into their police car. The officers drove Garfeed to a nearby location, and when Garfeed complained about the pain from his head injury, he was told to “Shut the f**k up.” Johnson smacked Garfeed in the face, cutting his lip, and when Garfeed protested, Johnson hit him repeatedly with both hands. Garfeed, who was handcuffed, put his head down while the officer hit him on his face, head and ear. Johnson threatened to beat him again if Garfeed continued to talk. Afraid of another beating, Garfeed stayed quiet while the officers sat in the car, waiting until they would be called to make another arrest. Soon after, the officers picked up another arrestee and drove both to a police station, where Garfeed was held overnight.

Williams was driving on the city's North Side with three of his friends when Officer Barney and another officer began following them. The officers pulled the car over and approached. Barney reached inside the car, pulled Williams out and handcuffed him. No one else in the car was handcuffed. Barney walked Williams to the police car, where he was pushed onto the backseat floor and punched in the face several times. Barney choked Williams and banged his head repeatedly against the car floor. When he was done, Barney pulled Williams up by his handcuffed wrists to sit him up in the backseat. The officers let Williams’ friends go, and they drove Williams to a CTA “L” station, where they released him without charging him with any crime. As a result of his injuries, Williams required medical care.

﻿Several police officers broke into Bussie’s apartment while she was away and searched it. The officers had a search warrant for a different building on Bussie’s block. The officers flipped over mattresses and opened drawers, dumping their contents on the floor. They didn’t find any contraband in Bussie’s home, and left a copy of the warrant they had for the other building as well as Officer Kwasinski’s business card on Bussie’s refrigerator. When Bussie returned home that evening, she found the doors to her apartment open. Several valuable items were missing from her home, including her television, laptop, a watch, jewelry, a leather coat and two pairs of shoes. She called Officer Kwasinski, who admitted the officers had searched the wrong building.

Haitham had purchased Legos for his son at a Target. He believed the set was missing some pieces and returned to the store, where a customer service representative told Haitham he could exchange the Legos. Since the set Haitham previously bought was out of stock, Haitham asked to exchange the Legos for a set of equal or lesser value. The customer service representative called the store manager to assist, and the manager asked Haitham for the receipt from his original purchase. Unable to find the receipt, Haitham left the store and returned a few moments later after finding the receipt in his pocket. Haitham asked to speak with the manager, who called the police and asked Haitham to leave the store. Officer Lindahl responded to the call, arrested Haitham for disorderly conduct and trespassing and brought Haitham to a police station. Once there, Lindahl told Haitham he hoped Haitham would sue him so he could get some overtime. Five months later, the charges against Haitham were dropped.

Vogler was at his home when he called the police because of a disturbance. When the officers arrived, they exchanged words with him outside. Without provocation, Officer Qualls tackled and choked Vogler, and Officer Cipicchio failed to intervene.

Franklin, who was pregnant at the time, was at her apartment when Officers Godinez, Tuman, Garcia, Glynn, Perez, Jara, Tyse and others entered her home and arrested her. Franklin's wrist was sprained during the arrest. Officer Tyse would not allow Franklin to dress, other than wrapping herself in a blanket, before being taken to a police station, where she was handcuffed to a bench. Tyse also threatened to tase her. Later, Franklin was admitted to a hospital against her will by Officers Halerz and Quinones. Franklin was not charged with an offense.

﻿Miller drove to a grocery store, parked his car in the parking lot and entered the store. After hearing his license plate number called on the store’s public address system, Miller went to the service desk. Officer Johnson met him at the desk and told him to walk to the parking lot with her. Johnson told Miller he had parked too closely to her squad car and she could not fully open her driver’s side door. When Miller said he would move his car, Johnson asked to see his driver’s license and insurance and told Miller she was going to give him a ticket. Miller pulled out his phone and told Johnson he was going to record their conversation on video. Miller also noted that Johnson’s squad car was parked over the lines and partially in his car’s space. Johnson grabbed Miller’s arm, and when Miller pulled away, the officer called for backup officers. Despite Miller showing his license, Johnson arrested and handcuffed Miller and placed him in her squad car. Johnson and another officer who arrived at the scene searched Miller’s car and drove Miller to a police station, where he was handcuffed to the wall in a holding cell for eight hours. Miller was charged with battery to an officer, criminal damage to property and aggravated assault of a police officer. Miller was released on bond and was told that his cellphone had been confiscated by the police. Six months later, the charges against Miller were dropped and he received his cellphone. Many of the photos and videos Miller had taken were erased from his phone.

As an employee of a community-based organization, Edwards was in charge of collecting biographical data on applicants to a an assistance program for low-income citizens. Edwards often worked offsite and kept her work documents at home. Edwards was at home when Officer Garcia and others forced their way inside, seizing her work documents. These papers were not returned within a reasonable time, and the seizure led to employment consequences against Edwards and the loss of services for low-income citizens. The officers portrayed Edwards in a negative light to her coworkers and her employer, and when Edwards complained, the officers reported Edwards to the city’s Building Inspection Division for code violations.

Murray was going to volunteer at a community center in the Uptown neighborhood. He had parked his car in a nearby lot when a police officer walked up to the driver’s side door of Murray’s car. He asked for Murray’s driver’s license, which Murray provided. Another officer arrived, and the officers asked Murray why he was there. Murray said he was planning to volunteer at a nearby community center. The officers told Murray to get out of his car. One of the officers took Murray's driver's license and returned to his unmarked police car, while another officer made Murray turn around and stand against his car to be searched. Murray complied. One of the officers asked if he could search Murray's car, to which Murray objected. Despite his objection, the officers searched the car. The officers did not find anything illegal on Murray or in his car.

﻿Leroy Hubbard was walking home when Officers Rake, Mackowiak and Swiatkowski pulled up next to him in an unmarked SUV. Rake ordered Hubbard to walk toward the officers’ car, but Hubbard ignored him and continued walking home. The officers followed Hubbard home in the SUV. Hubbard entered his home, and Rake followed him in without a warrant or consent. Once inside, Rake grabbed Hubbard by the jacket and pushed him against the wall, kicking him in the legs. Mackowiak and Swiatkowski entered the home, and within minutes, Officers Serrano, Blackman and others arrived as well. Rake and Mackowiak pushed Hubbard’s face against the wall, choked him and put him in handcuffs. Leroy Hubbard’s mother, Anita Hubbard, 55, was hooked up to a dialysis machine in the home when the officers entered. One of the officers pushed Anita Hubbard to the ground, nearly causing her dialysis machine to disconnect from her body. Hubbard’s cousin, K.H., 14, began recording the incident on her iPad, and one of the officers told her to stop recording, pulled her hair and tried to take her iPad. The officers took Hubbard outside to an SUV, searched him and found a pocket knife in his pocket. Rake charged Hubbard with battery to a police officer, resisting arrest and sale or possession of a deadly weapon. The charges against him were dismissed nine months later.

Around 9:45 p.m., officers responded to a call of a man breaking into cars at 41st Street and Kildare Avenue. Two officers responded and reported that a man was walking through the street with a knife in his hand. They requested assistance from “someone with a Taser.” One of the officers followed McDonald on foot while the other drove his police vehicle slowly alongside. The officers again requested a Taser and continued to follow McDonald as he turned south on Pulaski Road. Several other police vehicles arrived on the scene and positioned themselves in front of and behind McDonald. Officers Van Dyke and Walsh drove up in their marked Chevy Tahoe, parked in the middle of Pulaski, immediately exited their vehicles and drew their weapons. McDonald immediately changed direction, jogging away from the officers as he crossed Pulaski Road. Officer Van Dyke began shooting, hitting McDonald, the force of the bullet spinning him around. As McDonald fell to the ground on his right side, Officer Van Dyke continued shooting, ultimately hitting McDonald with 16 bullets throughout his body. Although there were at least 10 officers on the scene, only Van Dyke felt the need to use deadly force. After shooting him, Officer Van Dyke walked up to McDonald and kicked the knife out of his hand. McDonald, who was 17 years old, was pronounced dead at Mt. Sinai Hospital at 10:42 p.m. After the shooting, officers took one witness to a police station and questioned her for six hours, repeatedly trying to get her to change her story that McDonald was not a threat to the officers when Van Dyke shot him, telling her that her story “did not match the video,” which they refused to show her. Also after the shooting, several officers entered the Burger King at 4060 S. Pulaski Road and demanded the password to the surveillance video system. Officers were in the Burger King for several hours, and in the morning, the store manager and district manager found that 86 minutes of video from each of the 13 Burger King surveillance cameras were missing.

Neighborhood residents held a block party to celebrate two local teenagers who had signed a recording contract with a music label in Atlanta. When Officers Kahn and Zayas arrived, they began verbally harassing and assaulting the partygoers. When Simmons asked why the officers were accosting her 21-year-old son, Kahn slammed her body and head onto the hood of a patrol car. Kahn pulled out his baton, walked toward Smith and struck him in the head, causing him to collapse. Kahn and Zayas then arrested Smith and Simmons and took them to the police station. The officers then falsely charged Simmons with drinking on a public way, and Smith with battery, resisting arrest and unauthorized use of a weapon. Kahn told Smith that if he requested medical treatment for his head wound, Smith would be sent to Cook County Jail. Smith did not ask for medical treatment, but he was held and transported to jail anyway, where he spent 12 days before pleading guilty to simple battery so that he would be released. Kahn testified against Simmons at her trial, but she was acquitted.

Beck, Perkins, Moton and White were at home with children when several police officers entered and searched the house without knocking or providing a warrant. The officers damaged property and held the plaintiffs at gunpoint. Officers Zarbock and Hronopoulos falsely charged Beck with drug possession, but the charge was terminated a few weeks later.

﻿The plaintiffs, a husband and wife, were headed home after visiting with their daughter. Claxton, the husband, worked in security for a construction company. He lived with Skipper, his wife, in the buildings that were under construction to keep an eye on them. The plaintiffs had a security code to enter the building they were assigned to live in the night they were walking home. As the couple neared the entrance, a squad car drove onto the curb of the sidewalk, blocking their path. Officers Ryan and Adcock ordered Claxton to put his hands on the hood of the squad car and to show them identification. Claxton did as he was told and then asked why he was being arrested. An officer answered using a racial slur. As Claxton was being handcuffed, the other officer stood near Skipper. When she asked why her husband was being arrested, the officer said, “Get your crack head ass away.” Skipper moved away from the squad car and decided to go into the building. As she walked away, an officer followed her and hit her with a flashlight or similar object, knocking her to the ground. The officers then put Claxton into their squad car headfirst and drove him around the corner to a nearby alley. An officer told Claxton he had a "smart mouth" before one or more officers began to beat him with batons until he blacked out. When Claxton regained consciousness, he was handcuffed to a wall in a police station holding cell. He asked for medical help and was taken to a hospital, where he was treated for severe head injuries and abrasions. As Claxton received medical treatment, officers stayed in or near his room in a threatening manner. When Claxton was released from custody at the hospital, he was charged with drinking alcohol on a public sidewalk.

Martin was in her friend’s parked car across the street from her South Chicago home when she saw a gray unmarked police car speeding north without its lights or sirens on. The car turned around and headed south, this time with its lights on, and parked next to the car Martin was in. When one officer got out and asked Martin to get out, she asked why and the officer cursed at her, pulled her out of the car and slammed her against it, then twisted her arm behind her back and slammed her against the car several more times. When she complained, the officer held her more tightly, handcuffed her and walked her over to the unmarked police car. The officers took the car keys from Martin’s friend, handcuffed him and searched the car but found nothing illegal. Martin’s friend was given a ticket for not having a Chicago car registration sticker. Police then drove the unmarked car around the neighborhood and discussed what to do with Martin. The officers threatened to take her to a police station before letting her go a block away from her home. Martin went to the hospital for medical treatment and was found to have a fractured clavicle.

Cook was driving when Officers Whitmer and Jagla pulled him over and arrested him. Cook, who had severe asthma, began to have an asthma attack. Whitmer and Jagla called for Sergeant Truhlar, and Cook tried to explain that he could not breathe and needed medical care. The officers and sergeant did not provide Cook with any medical care, and Cook died.

Wilson was driving his car in the Calumet Heights neighborhood when officers pulled him over, searched him and arrested him. Although Wilson had a valid permit to carry a concealed firearm, he was charged with aggravated unlawful use of a weapon and jailed. The charges against him were dropped.
Segal, who was with Mandeldove at the time, began recording police with a cellphone. The officers noticed they were being recorded and arrested Segal and Mandeldove.

Winston, 68, lives in a second-floor apartment and works as a maid. Chapman, 62, lives on the first floor with her husband. Ivory, 44, lives in the basement apartment. Winston was carrying in groceries with help from Ivory when police officers arrived at their building in squad cars. Without consent or a warrant, officers kicked in the building's front door and entered the building while other officers broke into a rear door. When Winston and Ivory tried to go inside to see what the officers were doing, they were ordered to stay outside with some of the officers. Chapman was inside her home when officers entered to search, looking through her closets and drawers. Officers removed clothing from Ivory's closets, turned his mattress upside down and opened drawers and cabinets. The officers failed to find any illegal items. Sergeant Talley told Winston to call 311 to have the city pay for the damage to their front door, and the officers drove away.

Rocha was fighting with a friend and the friend’s brother in the Brighton Park neighborhood. Several police offers arrived at the scene and attempted to subdue Rocha. Although the officers saw Rocha pleading for help, none of the officers offered to assist him. As a result of the fight and the officers’ use of force, Rocha suffered serious injuries that led to his death.

Murphy was on a CTA Red Line train heading to work when officers arrested him. Murphy had paid for his ticket and was not breaking any laws. In the course of handcuffing him, Officer Mabery struck Murphy's hand with a police baton. After being transported to the police station, Murphy was denied medical treatment for his hand, which was swollen and painful. He was also denied treatment for his epilepsy. He was subsequently charged with trespassing and resisting/obstructing a peace officer. The charges were later dropped.

Alejandre, Jaime and their dogs were inside a gated courtyard within Jaime's apartment complex when Officer Salgado threatened to shoot the animals if they were not put on leashes. Salgado then locked the two women inside of the courtyard, entered Jaime's apartment and searched it. Once the women were able to escape the courtyard, Alejandre began to record Salgado's misconduct on her cellphone. Noticing this, Salgado forcefully detained Alejandre and Jaime, who was pregnant, as they attempted to keep hold of the phone. The phone eventually fell and Salgado took it. He left Jaime's apartment, searched Alejandre's phone and erased the video that she recorded.

Sellers, a nurse at a hospital, was at work when police came to her apartment and knocked to come in during a search of other apartments in the building. Sellers’ boyfriend, Demarcus Bell, was there with her four children and asked to see a warrant. Police had none, and kicked in Sellers’ door and burst in with their guns drawn. Bell asked why they entered without permission and demanded again to see a search warrant. One officer picked up a piece of mail and said, "Here's your search warrant. Bell was handcuffed and taken outside. Police then pointed their guns at the four children

Hardman was a guest at an apartment when police arrived and said they had received a noise complaint. Hardman was in a T-shirt and underwear and didn't want to open the door completely, but police came in the apartment anyway and demanded Hardman's identification even though she told police it wasn't her apartment. Officer Robinson told Hardman and the apartment's leaseholder to shut up and turn down their music. Hardman was uncomfortable with Robinson’s aggressive behavior and called her father. Robinson became angry and ordered her to end the call. Hardman said she would lower the phone but would keep her father on the line until police left because she was uncomfortable with their actions. Robinson then grabbed Hardman's arm, twisted it behind her and handcuffed her, then paraded Hardman down the street in her T-shirt and underwear, refusing to allow her to get dressed. Hardman was charged with resisting a police officer and a noise ordinance violation. She was found not guilty.

﻿Young held a barbecue at her mother’s home to honor the life of her son, who was 20 when he was shot and killed by a Chicago police officer. That evening, several officers, including Officers Salvador and Kilponen, arrived and told Young to end the event. Salvador and Kilponen started yelling at Young, who began to ask visitors to leave. When Young was preparing to leave, Salvador demanded to see her identification. When she said it was in her purse inside her mother’s home, Salvador said, “F**k it, you are going to jail.” He arrested Young, handcuffed her and put her in a squad car. Kilponen wrote a citation and asked Young to sign it while Salvador yelled at Young, saying he did not kill her son. Young, who did not know what the citation was for, refused to sign it. The officers took Young to a police station, where Officers Johnson and Hoover approved her arrest on charges of “storing goods in a public way.” She was held at the station for 31 hours. One month later, at her first court hearing, Young asked for and received an order of preservation for the citation and a copy of all documents related to her arrest. However, the officers failed to produce the citation. The case was closed and the charges dropped.
Robinson was in the Auburn Gresham neighborhood when Officers Mendoza, Wagner and Garza shot and killed Robinson without lawful justification or excuse.

Smith is a disabled military veteran who won several Bronze Stars, ribbons and medals for his service. Smith suffers from post-traumatic stress disorder and was diagnosed as 100 percent disabled. Smith was with a friend at a laundromat when he stepped outside and a man handed Smith a beer. Officer Manning and his partner drove up to Smith in an unmarked car and got out. Manning placed his hand on his gun. Fearing for his safety, Smith ran from the officers, and Manning called on the radio for additional officers to pursue Smith for drinking on a public way. Several officers arrived and began chasing Smith, who hopped a fence, ran through an apartment building and exited through the back door, where he was met by several officers with their guns drawn. The officers yelled contradictory orders to get on the ground, turn around and put his hands up all at once. Smith put his hands up and began screaming, hoping to draw attention from nearby residents. Manning opened fire, and Officer Davilla and Sergeant Finley began shooting at Smith as well. Smith was struck by five bullets in his chest, arm and legs, and grazed by two bullets on his face and neck. The officers gave false accounts of the events to supervisors at the scene, which were then repeated in news reports. As a result of the shooting, Smith was permanently disfigured and disabled.

Bellamy was at the park with a few friends. Officer Watkins was working as an armed security guard for a local business when he got into an argument with Bellamy, grabbed her by the throat, threw her to the ground and jumped on top of her. Two other officers were told to investigate what happened. Although Bellamy and her friends told the officers that Watkins had attacked Bellamy, the officers arrested Bellamy and took her to jail. Watkins was not arrested. The officers tried to charge Bellamy with aggravated battery to an officer, but the charges were not approved. They gave false accounts of the evidence, created false reports and charged Bellamy with misdemeanor battery. When Bellamy was released from jail, she went to a hospital to receive medical care for her injuries. At Bellamy’s trial three months later, the officers failed to show up and the criminal charge against Bellamy was dismissed.

Cartagena was in line to enter a nightclub when two bouncers who were patting down individuals found a handgun on a person wearing a red shirt. The recovery of the gun was recorded on the club’s security cameras, and the bouncers called the police. Meanwhile, Cartagena left the line and began walking away. Officers Schurman and Murphy responded to the call, spoke with the bouncers, and stopped and searched Cartagena without cause a few blocks away. The officers arrested Cartagena on suspicion of unlawful possession of a gun even though they never saw Cartagena with a gun and the security footage showed the offender wearing a red shirt. The officers signed false reports against Cartagena and fabricated a confession. Cartagena was falsely charged with and prosecuted for multiple felony offenses. He was imprisoned until the charges were dismissed six months later.

Jordan was arrested outside a police station in the Greater Grand Crossing neighborhood by Officers Barr and Romero. He was charged with aggravated assault of a police officer, criminal trespass to land and violation of bail bond. The charges were later dropped.

Williams was attending festivities for the annual Chicago Pride Parade when she was approached by police officers. The officers snatched Williams'cup, threw it to the ground and arrested her for drinking alcohol in public, even though she had been drinking soda. Williams was taken to a police station and held in a cell for more than eight hours before being released and charged for drinking on a public way.

﻿Ross was outside about a block from her house in the Auburn Gresham neighborhood when she saw Officers Flores and Hernandez pull up in a police car, get out and start assaulting an African-American man. Ross questioned the officers’ actions and asked Flores why the man was being arrested. Flores hit Ross above the eye with a baton, cutting her right eyebrow. The officers then tackled Ross to the ground and arrested her. Ross was taken to a hospital to receive stitches for the cut above her eye. The officers filed false reports charging Ross with assault, battery and resisting arrest. Two months later, the charges against her were dismissed.
Allen was at home when Officers Ewing and Puszkiewicz entered without a warrant and knocked her to the floor, injuring her.

Diaz and Garrett were riding their bicycles in the University Village neighborhood when they were stopped by two officers. When the two asked why the officers stopped them, they were not given a reason. Diaz called her father, who worked in law enforcement and told her not to sign anything without reading it first. One of the officers told Garrett and Diaz that they were not allowed to bike on that street. When police wrote them tickets, Diaz was grabbed and handcuffed when she would not immediately sign it. Garrett began to record the incident on his phone and one officer snatched the phone from him, grabbing his arm and swinging him into a fence. Garrett was charged with battery, assault, resisting arrest and obstruction. Diaz was charged with resisting arrest and obstruction of traffic by a motorist. The two were held in custody for the night. The charges were later dismissed.

﻿Lewis was in a car with license plates that registered as a stolen vehicle when he was pulled over by police officers who were following a car chase. Lewis got out of the car and ran away from the officers. Officer Nutile chased Lewis and tackled him to the ground. He pinned Lewis’ hands behind his back and began punching Lewis on the right side of his face while calling him a “black motherf**ker.” Officers Michna, Husic and Schaffer were all present during this assault. After Nutile handcuffed Lewis, who was still facedown on the ground, Husic kicked the left side of Lewis’ face. When a bystander called out to the officers to question their use of force, Michna threatened the witness to stay quiet. Husic told the other officers to report that Lewis was injured from running and falling. Lewis’ right eye was swollen shut due to internal bleeding around his eye socket, and he was dizzy and in pain. The officers called for an ambulance, and Lewis was taken to a hospital, then transferred to a different hospital. Lewis received multiple stitches on the inside and outside of his mouth, and his eye socket was fractured and torn. 
Several hours later, Lewis was taken to a police station and placed in a holding cell, where he later spoke with an investigator from the Independent Police Review Authority. The investigator took photos of Lewis’ injuries, but never contacted him again. The next day, Lewis was taken to Cook County Jail.

﻿When Barron arrived home from work around 9:30 p.m., his key broke off in the lock on his front door. After trying to remove the key, Barron climbed onto a dumpster to see if he could gain access to his back patio door, which is attached to his garage roof. After determining it would be too dangerous, Barron returned to the main entrance and spoke with a neighbor, who provided some hand tools to try and remove the broken key from the lock. Several minutes later, Officer Moy approached the two men and aggressively told Barron to stay off the garage roof. When Barron explained he was locked out of his home, Moy responded with profanity, said he had called the police and drove away. Barron’s neighbor explained that Moy was a police officer who lived nearby. Soon after, two police officers arrived in a Chicago Police Department SUV and said they had been called about a man on a roof. Barron explained the situation. “Cool,” one of the officers replied, and without exiting their vehicle, the officers drove away. Barron’s neighbor left, and Barron decided to climb onto the roof. Once there, he heard a voice screaming, “Get on the f**king ground.” It was Moy, standing on the back porch of a nearby residence, pointing a handgun at Barron. He told Barron he was under arrest and threatened to shoot him if he did not get on the ground. Barron obeyed, and Moy held him at gunpoint for 15 minutes while waiting for other officers to arrive. Once the officers came, Moy lied and told them Barron climbed over his fence into his backyard, screamed incoherently on Moy’s back porch, banged on Moy’s back door and threatened him with an AIDS needle. Barron was falsely charged and arrested with criminal trespass and disorderly conduct. The charges were dropped one year later.

﻿After working most of the day as a construction contractor, Cadle went to visit a friend at his home on the South Side. Cadle parked his car in the back of his friend’s home and began talking to the friend in the garage. Soon after, two police officers approached him and asked who owned the car in the garage. When Cadle replied that he did, one of the officers demanded to see his license and registration. When Cadle asked why he was being questioned, the officer falsely accused him of a traffic violation. Although he denied the allegations, Cadle provided his license and registration. His friend asked why Cadle was cooperating. Cadle allowed the officers to search his car and give him a sobriety test, which he passed. Even though they didn’t find any contraband in Cadle’s car, the officers falsely accused him of having open alcohol in the backseat. One of the officers then grabbed Cadle, slammed him into a nearby gate, shoved him to the ground and struck him in the ribs. Cadle felt pain in his chest and had difficulty breathing. The officers handcuffed Cadle, shackled his legs together and threw him in the backseat of their car. They drove Cadle to a police station, where he was locked up despite his repeated requests for medical care. After several hours, a police officer transported Cadle in the back of a paddy wagon to a hospital, where Cadle was diagnosed with a punctured lung, two broken ribs and a fractured collarbone. Cadle was falsely charged with resisting arrest and several traffic citations, including illegal transportation of alcohol. After eight months, all of the charges and citations against Cadle were dropped.

Smith, James and Allen were walking up 63rd Street near South Indiana Avenue when they saw police pull over an elderly woman. The three women said that it was a shame that officers were questioning an elderly woman when real crime needed to be investigated. Hearing this comment, a male officer grabbed the three women, handcuffed them, then threw them against the police car. One male officer pushed and scratched Smith and made angry, racist and derogatory remarks, then threatened to take the women to jail and searched their pockets. When the women protested, a female officer took over the search and took ID cards from them. Police searched their names in a database and the three women were later let go.

﻿James provides cleaning and decluttering services and is authorized to remove all items from his clients’ homes. He was cleaning a client’s house when he found an antique gun, which he placed inside a gun case and under a blanket. James was taking the gun outside to his car when Officers Rivera, Styczynski, and Jauregui stopped and searched him. When the officers found the antique gun, they arrested James and took him to a police station. James was falsely charged with aggravated unlawful use of a weapon, and was kept in custody for 39 days before posting bond. He was found not guilty eight months later.

﻿Owens arrived at a friend’s house around 7 p.m. The two relaxed and talked outside on the front porch with a third friend. Around 9:30 p.m., an unmarked police car pulled up to the home, and one of the officers inside shined the car light on the three men sitting outside. The car drove away, and 10 minutes later several marked and unmarked police cars arrived at the home. Several officers ordered the men to get off the porch, and began running their names and the license plates of their cars. 
When Owens asked Officer Evans what was going on, he told Owens to shut up. When Owens repeated the question, Evans said if Owens did not shut up, he would lock Owens up, purposefully make mistakes on his paperwork and send him to Louisiana or Alabama. Evans told another officer to handcuff Owens, and Owens was handcuffed, searched and put in the back of a squad car even though officers found no contraband. The officers searched the home’s yard and front porch with flashlights, and questioned Owens repeatedly. About 30 minutes later, Evans asked Owens to sign a drinking ticket. Since Owens had not been drinking, he refused. Evans threatened to put Owens in jail if he did not sign the ticket, but Owens refused again. Evans left Owens and returned 10 minutes later, saying he was free to go. The officers never explained why they were at the home.

Police officers arrested Stuckey without cause or warrant in the Rogers Park neighborhood. They filed false reports alleging that Stuckey had committed crimes, including unlawful use of a weapon and reckless conduct. About nine months later, Stuckey was found not guilty of all charges.

Toplin was riding his bike in the Gage Park neighborhood when Officers Garza and Habiak tried to stop him. Toplin refused to stop and talk, so Garza and Habiak punched and kicked him. They arrested Toplin on suspicion of aggravated battery. The false charge was later dismissed.

﻿Foster was walking along a sidewalk to a CTA station in the South Austin neighborhood when Officers Fumo and Vidljinovic called her over to their patrol car. When she approached, Fumo grabbed one of Foster's arms while Vidljinovic grabbed the other. Fumo bent and twisted her arm, injuring Foster's wrist. The officers then used a “takedown” move, causing Foster to fall to the ground. While Foster was facedown on the ground, Fumo used his knee to put pressure on her back. Foster did not resist the officers at any time but was arrested  and charged with assault and resisting an officer. Foster was found not guilty.

Tharp and Richard, who lived in south suburban Homewood, left a barbershop in the Woodlawn neighborhood to walk to a nearby convenience store. They were immediately stopped by Sgt. Rashan, who searched both men, demanded to see their ID, then accused them of gang loitering and ordered them to go home. They told the sergeant that they could not go home right away because they did not live in Chicago, and Rashan threatened to arrest them if he saw them again. When Tharp and Richard walked back to the barbershop to wait inside for a friend, Rashan walked in behind them and arrested them. Their friend told the sergeant that the men were with him, had no connection to the area and were not in a gang. But Rashan called more officers to the scene and the two were taken to a police station and charged with gang loitering. The charges were later dropped.

Mims was arrested and thrown to the ground by the arresting officers. He complained of severe pain to his arm while on the ground and at a police station where he was detained. Officers at the station ignored Mims' continued complaints and threatened to file more criminal charges if he did not stop. Mim’s injury required multiple surgeries to his elbow.

﻿J.B., 17, was driving in an alley in the Englewood neighborhood as Officers Bedoy and Smolek pursued him in a squad car. The officers hit J.B.’s car, seriously injuring him. The officers falsely claimed J.B. jumped on their car and charged him with reckless damage to property. The charge was dismissed nearly one year later.

﻿Giljen was returning home with his wife and children around 5:30 p.m. At a Red Line station, his wife used her Ventra card to pay for her fare, and then passed through the handicap gate because she had a toddler in a stroller. Giljen used his Ventra card twice, to pay for himself and his 9-year-old son. When Giljen joined his family in the station, a police officer approached him and accused Giljen of not paying his fare. The officer took Giljen’s Ventra card and tapped it at another turnstile, deducting an additional fare from the card’s balance. Giljen offered to log into his Ventra account and his bank account to prove he had already paid and asked the officer to speak with a Chicago Transit Authority (CTA) employee to verify Giljen’s payment. Another officer arrived, and the officers grabbed Giljen’s arm and told him he was under arrest. The officers threatened to throw Giljen to the ground, handcuffed him and took him to a room at the station, where they searched him. One of the officers took Giljen’s identification and Ventra card and spoke with a CTA employee. The officer took Giljen to a police station, where he was searched again.  Giljen was handcuffed in lockup for several hours before he was released. Giljen was charged with theft of labor/services/property. The criminal case was dismissed.

McCastle was driving her car when Officers Chevalier and Carrasco pulled her over and asked for her license, registration and proof of insurance. The officers returned to their car, then came back to McCastle’s car and ordered her to get out because she was playing her music too loudly. When McCastle denied this, the officers arrested her and slammed her against her car. McCastle was charged with reckless conduct and resisting arrest. The officers also impounded her car. At trial, McCastle was found not guilty of both charges.

Jones-Huff was in the backyard of her home in the Auburn Gresham neighborhood when she noticed a neighbor’s flower pot was leaning on her fence. Her neighbors were Officer Hill and his wife. Jones-Huff pushed the pot off the fence with a stick, and Hill’s wife ran out of her home yelling obscenities at Jones-Huff. Hill’s wife then tossed dirt over the fence onto Jones-Huff’s head. Police were called to the scene, and shortly before they arrived, Jones-Huff’s husband went inside their home and returned with a shotgun. He shot Hill’s wife once in the arm. Hill, then off-duty, shot Jones-Huff’s husband nine times, killing him. Jones-Huff tried to get to her husband, but Hill turned his gun on her and shot her twice. Jones-Huff was taken to the hospital for her injuries. Hill attempted to charge the 91-year-old woman with aggravated assault to a police officer and battery, claiming that the 5-foot Jones-Huff had reached over the 6-foot fence to strike him and his wife on the head with a broom. Jones-Huff was found not guilty.

Clemons visited his daughter’s apartment around 1 a.m. and began arguing with his son-in-law. Clemons’ daughter called the police and asked for an officer to come to the apartment. Officers Branch and Van Dyke responded to her call, and spoke with Clemons’ son-in-law, who asked the officers to make Clemons leave. The officers took Clemons outside and began to grab, push and hit him. The officers hit Clemons in the face and head with a baton, knocking him unconscious. They threw him to the ground, handcuffed him and continued to beat him. The officers took Clemons to a police station, where he was processed and put in a cell. Clemons was released on bond several hours later, and went to a hospital, where he was treated for facial fractures, swelling, bruising, concussion, blurred visions, cuts, scrapes and migraines.

J.A. was walking with his mother, McGee, and her friend in the Chatham neighborhood when several officers came up, grabbed him and made repeated statements about a gun. McGee told the officers that her son was only 10 years old and didn’t know about any guns. Police searched J.A. and found nothing. They put him in the back of the squad car. McGee called 911 and asked to speak to a supervisor. Meanwhile, more officers arrived, and J.A. was taken to a police station. Sgt. Reynolds refused to tell McGee why her son was being arrested. At the station, officers swore and yelled at J.A. while questioning him about gang activity, frightening the boy, who had no information about gangs. McGee was not permitted to see her son, and officers laughed at and ridiculed her, threatening to arrest her and charge her with child neglect. J.A. was released, but issued a citation for urinating in public. McGee believes that the incident was the result of racial discrimination, as she and her son are African- American and the officers are white.

Resendiz, then 19, was riding with a friend in his friend’s car in the Garfield Ridge neighborhood when they were pulled over by police. Resendiz and his friend are Latino. The officers involved are white and also lived in Garfield Ridge, where they were known for patrolling the neighborhood and had “engaged in a pattern of violations as part of an effort to control the non-Caucasian residents.” Officer Campbell dragged Resendiz out of the car, grabbed him by the hair, slammed his face into the car, handcuffed him and searched him. The officers took Resendiz to a police station and charged him with possession of a controlled substance after they claimed to have found two small pills on him. The charge was later dismissed.

Palmer, who is diabetic and requires four insulin shots daily, was arrested in the morning and taken to a police station, where several officers took his insulin. Palmer told the officers several times that he needed insulin. He became weak, unable to walk and vomited several times throughout the rest of the day. The following morning, the officers transported Palmer, who was visibly dehydrated, to a hospital for medical treatment. After receiving an IV of fluids, Palmer was given the wrong type of insulin, but was transported back to the police station anyway. He did not receive medical care again until late that night, when he was taken to a different hospital where his insulin could be properly administered. On the brink of a diabetic coma, Palmer remained at the hospital for several days.

Fulson was at his business in the Calumet Heights neighborhood when Officer Robinson arrived and began to argue with him about an incident down the street. Fulson had no connection to the incident and had not committed a crime but was taken into custody and put in a squad car as officers searched his business without a warrant. Officers claimed to have found contraband. As a result, Robinson and Officers Kasput, Vazquez, Venegas and Murzyn charged Fulson with criminal drugs and firearms charges. Fulson, a diabetic, was taken to a police station for processing, but was not given the insulin he repeatedly told officers he needed. Eventually an ambulance was called for Fulson. He was detained in jail for two months, and the charges were later dismissed.

Vasquez was driving home from work when Officers Higgs and Leonard stopped him and accused him of driving a stolen car. Despite the fact that Vasquez did not match the suspect they were searching for and was not committing any crime, the officers arrested Vasquez.

Tapia and Hernandez were gathering signatures on a petition and passing out information for the Brighton Park Neighborhood Council and Grassroots Collaborative when Officers Ryan and Stark stopped them, searched them and asked what they were doing. Tapia and Hernandez said they were canvassing, but police put them in a squad car, reviewed their identification and searched their backpacks. While this was happening, Officer Murphy and two other officers arrived and began asking Tapia and Hernandez about their canvassing. Ryan questioned Tapia about his name and the fact that his cell-phone number was from out-of-state. Tapia and Hernandez were searched again, then handcuffed and put back in the squad car. Police charged them with unlawful solicitation. The charges were later dismissed.

Smith was driving with a friend in the Homan Square neighborhood, when he was pulled over by police without cause. The officers arrested Smith for possession of heroin, even though he didn't have any heroin in his possession.

B.Q. was riding his bike with a friend when Officers Campbell and Foley stopped them and brought them to a nearby home for a show-up. Although they weren’t identified as suspects in criminal activity, B.Q. and his friend were brought to a police station and arrested for criminal charges. B.Q. was given notice to appear in court a few weeks later, where all charges were dropped.

Diaz was standing at a bus stop when officers investigating an attempted burglary nearby arrested him. A 12-year-old witness had told officers that she saw two men wearing all black with black backpacks. Diaz was wearing blue jeans, white sneakers and a black coat, and had a gold and black backpack. Officers manipulated the 12-year-old, telling her they were showing her a man who may have been one of the attempted burglars before bringing in Diaz. Later, officers falsified paperwork to make it appear that the witness had specified that the attempted burglars were two "Hispanic males." Based on the 12-year-old's identification, Diaz was arrested and spent over a year in jail awaiting trial before he was acquitted of all charges.

Parks was pulling out of a parking space in the lot of a McDonald’s restaurant when two police cars jammed the front and rear of the his van. Officer Mingari got out of the police car and quickly fired three gunshots at the van, one of which punctured Parks’ lung.

Hobson was arrested at an apartment and strip-searched. Although they didn’t find anything illegal, the officers brought Hobson to a detention center nearly 12 miles away instead of the police station a few blocks from the apartment. The officers questioned Hobson about a murder investigation, and said Hobson could help himself by giving the officers information. When Hobson said he did not have any relevant information, the officers left. Later, Officers McFadden, Horton, Slechter and Gomez entered the room and pointed two Taser guns at Hobson. McFadden told Hobson to “get [his] black ass naked” or McFadden would use a Taser on Hobson “until he pissed and s**t himself.” The other officers taunted Hobson, hurling racial slurs at him and telling him to “hurry up” and “get his black ass naked right now” before he got “f**ked up” or “Tasered.” McFadden told Hobson to bend over and spread his butt cheeks. After Hobson obeyed, the officers repeatedly instructed Hobson to lift his penis and testicles, while one officer placed a Taser near Hobson’s testicles and threatened to use it on his genitals. During one of the strip searches, McFadden put on dirty leather gloves and ordered Hobson to open his mouth. McFadden put several fingers in Hobson’s mouth while three Tasers and a loaded gun were pointed at him. By this point, Hobson was naked and crying. McFadden then ordered Gomez to place his gun inside Hobson’s mouth. Gomez held his gun inside Hobson’s mouth for about three minutes, while the other officers joked that Gomez “should have put a condom on [his] gun before placing it in [Hobson’s] mouth.” Hobson eventually vomited several times in the interrogation room before being transported to Cook County Jail, where he informed a doctor about intense headaches.

﻿Vaughn was spending time at a former girlfriend’s apartment one winter afternoon when the two began to argue. Vaughn left the apartment, hoping she would calm down. When he returned later that evening, the argument resumed. She ordered him to leave and called the police. Vaughn left, but realized he had left his heavy winter jacket and walked back to retrieve it. While waiting to be let back into the apartment, Officers Akinbusuyi and Torres arrived at the scene and attempted to restrain and handcuff Vaughn without talking to him or his former girlfriend to assess the situation. Vaughn tried to avoid getting handcuffed, so the officers responded with more force, causing Vaughn and one or more of the officers to fall down a flight of stairs. Vaughn struck his head and face on the ground. He was then arrested and denied treatment for his injuries for several hours. The officers later falsely claimed they felt imminent danger upon seeing Vaughn alone outside the apartment.
Stevens was stopped by Officer Kilroy without probable cause and used excessive force, injuring Stevens.
Officer Kahn approached Lambert in the North Lawndale neighborhood. The officer hit and injured Lambert without reason or justification.

Several police officers arrested Green without a warrant and pretended Green had confessed to several crimes in their presence. The officers filed false reports against Green, who remained in jail for more than a year and a half until he was found not guilty.

Hairston was walking down the street when Officers Garcia, Thuestad and an unnamed officer pulled up and took him into custody. The officers asked Hairston if he owned guns, and told Hairston if he provided a gun they would release him. After riding in the car for some time, the officers arrested Hairston on suspicion of possession of a controlled substance.

Burns was walking home one evening in the Roseland neighborhood when officers tackled him and hit him in the head as he reached the back of his house. The officers continued to beat Burns with their fists and batons and never announced that they were police. When Burns said that he was in extreme pain and needed medical care, police threatened him. Bleeding from a head wound, Burns was taken to an unmarked police car near his home. He asked for medical help again, but was taken to a police station. There, he asked another officer for medical care and was denied again. Police later called an ambulance to take Burns to the hospital, where he was treated for a concussion and other injuries. Officers accused Burns of criminal activity in an attempt to cover up their misconduct.

Hanna Walker was inside Dion Walker’s home in Englewood when police forced their way in with a search warrant for an individual named ‘Gino’. Before obtaining the warrant, officers never saw ‘Gino’ enter or leave Walker’s home, and there was no known link between them. During the search, officers grabbed Hanna Walker and seized money that belonged to her and Dion Walker. They also confiscated a shotgun that was legally owned by Dion Walker. Police did not document that the items had been taken, and the property was never returned despite the Walkers’ repeated requests.

﻿Anderson, A.W. and D.W. were at home when Sergeant Stec and several police officers entered the home without knocking. Officer Matthews had a search warrant for an individual named “Gino” but did not have any proof linking Gino to Anderson’s home. The officers searched the home anyway without finding any illegal drugs, paraphernalia or Gino. The officers damaged property inside Anderson's home due to the forced entry.

Harrison was at her East Garfield Park apartment with her five children and other relatives when police burst in without a search warrant or consent demanding to know where to find drugs. Harrison told the officers she had no drugs, but they handcuffed her and Officer Cowie took her to the bathroom and strip-searched her while other officers watched. Cowie told Harrison, who was naked from the waist down, to bend over and cough multiple times so she could do a thorough search, then pulled Harrison’s T-shirt and bra up, fully exposing her. Police did not find any drugs in the apartment or on Harrison. Nevertheless, officers took her to the police station and filled out false police reports to back up their charges of possession of a controlled substance. The charges against Harrison were later dropped.

J.S., a minor, was in the South Shore neighborhood when Officers Concialdi, MacFarlane and Piechocki stopped her without any legal justification and searched her. Officers then took J.S. to the 5th District station and searched her again. J.S. was held in an interrogation room and unable to contact her mother for several hours. Officers Concialdi, MacFarlane, Piochocki and D'Amato also entered her home without any legal justification and searched it.

﻿Van der Vant lives in the Forest Glen neighborhood and has several police officers as neighbors. Shortly after van der Vant moved into her home, she decided to erect a fence around the perimeter of her property. When the officers who live around her learned of her plans they complained and protested. The plaintiff put up her fence anyway, and since then the officers have harassed her. The harassment has included officers putting empty ticket envelopes on van der Vant’s vehicle when it was parked outside her home and issuing complaints and threats over her barking dog. In one instance, Officer Hallinan got a call from an unknown officer who lived on van der Vant’s block complaining about her dog. Hallinan and Officers Aviles and Davis headed to the plaintiff's home and entered her fenced-off yard without permission to remove the collar from her dog's neck. Soon after, the plaintiff called her dog into her home and noticed the collar was missing. The next day she filed a police report for the missing collar. Hallinan called the plaintiff's husband later that day to say the collar had been recovered and was ready to be picked up at the Jefferson Park police station. It was urgent that it be picked up or the collar would not be available for several weeks, Hallinan said. Van der Vant’s husband called her and asked her to pick up the collar on her way home from work. When the plaintiff arrived at the station she asked for Hallinan, who requested her identification. After she presented her identification, officers surrounded the plaintiff and arrested her without justification on suspicion of animal abuse. Three veterinarians examined the plaintiff's dog after her arrest and concluded the dog was in good health. While she was in police custody and handcuffed for hours to a steel bench, van der Vant’s sciatica flared up, requiring hospitalization.
