While driving a semi-tractor trailer, Donald Wells rammed into the CTA station at Cermak Road and 22nd Street and was seriously injured. Police arrested Wells, who was 64 at the time, while he was still at the hospital and later took him to a police station. Wells stayed there for more than 48 hours, sleeping on a cold concrete floor and showing visible signs of illness from his injuries. He had difficulty standing and walking, moaned in pain, was disoriented, talked incoherently, was unable to answer questions, defecated and urinated on himself and did not eat or drink. Officers refused to provide medical attention for Wells, even though relatives and at least one attorney phoned police and pleaded for him to be returned to the hospital. When he was released, Wells was rushed via ambulance to a hospital for emergency treatment. He remained hospitalized for six weeks, then died.
Angel and Asia Moore were in the Auburn Gresham neighborhood when officers stopped and searched them without probable cause.

Brown was driving his car on South Lake Shore Drive when Officer Parker pulled him over and ordered him to the rear of the car. Parker had Brown take sobriety tests, all of which he passed. Despite any evidence of impairment, Parker arrested Brown on suspicion of driving under the influence.

While executing a search warrant, officers saw Porter in a parked car and went over to question him about someone nicknamed “Buttah.” The officers then searched and arrested Porter, charged him with possession of a controlled substance with intent to sell, and submitted false statements and police reports to back up the charges. Several months later, the charges against Porter were dismissed.

In 2008, Brewer left his home in Michigan to visit a Chicago police station, where his younger brother had been taken after being arrested in a sting operation targeting drug sales. Brewer had heard that officers had beaten his brother while arresting him, and Brewer wanted to learn more. After questioning the officers at the station, an officer told Brewer he needed to leave and threatened him with arrest. Brewer left and began to drive away when officers followed him and pulled over his vehicle. The officers ran a name check on him, which revealed no warrants, and they let him go. Several days later, Brewer was back in Michigan when a relative told him his photo was on the TV news as well as the internet, and that police claimed that Brewer was part of the drug-selling ring they were investigating. Eight months later, Brewer was visiting relatives in Oak Lawn when Oak Lawn police officers arrested him on a warrant for his alleged involvement in the drug conspiracy the Chicago police officers were investigating. At his bond hearing, Brewer was charged with four deliveries of narcotics to undercover officers and with being part of a drug conspiracy. Brewer could not afford to post his bail, and he remained in custody at the Cook County Jail for nine months. The trial judge dismissed the charges against Brewer, finding that the officers had incorrectly identified him.

Officers had set up a sting operation for a location in the Belmont Cragin neighborhood when Zarate walked in. Officers had been waiting for his arrival in order to arrest him. As he opened the door to the premises, the officers immediately opened fire on Zarate without announcing themselves as officers or providing him with verbal commands. Zarate slammed the door and ran, but was struck in the back by a shot fired by Officer Laska. He collapsed to the ground, and three officers rushed to him. They pushed their knees into his wounded back and forced their elbows into the back of his neck. He was handcuffed with his hands behind his back and turned over, his body weight pressing on his handcuffed hands, right where he had been shot. The officers cursed at him while he was lying on the ground, and one told him that he hoped that he would die. Zarate was transported to a hospital for treatment of his injuries.

Gonzalez was in front of a bar with his cousin in the South Lawndale neighborhood when officers handcuffed his hands behind his back and placed him facedown on the ground. The officers beat Gonzalez while he was on the ground. Additional officers arrived at the scene. Sgt. Hughes told his fellow officers to stand back, then tased Gonzalez for an excessive amount of time. Hughes shocked Gonzalez at least one more time after that. Then the officers beat Gonzalez and placed him in a hog-tied position -- his hands cuffed behind his back and his legs shackled. Throughout the incident, Gonzalez displayed obvious signs of distress and difficulty breathing. He was overweight, intoxicated and possibly high on cocaine. One of the officers pepper-sprayed Gonzalez in the face, brought him to the squad car and finally dropped him on the side of the car. They placed him in the squad car in the same hog-tied position. Gonzalez was eventually taken to the hospital, where he died later that night.

Jerome McNeal was in his third-floor apartment in the South Shore neighborhood with his minor son, J.M., and his wife, Donetta, when officers entered without a search warrant. J.M., who suffers from asthma, was receiving a breathing treatment from a nebulizer machine. Jerome McNeal asked the officers to show him a warrant. Barroso and one or more other officers threw him to the ground, stomped on his left knee and struck him on the left side of this head with a blunt object. He was placed in handcuffs and taken to the apartment’s back porch. By then, officers had taken J.M. off the nebulizer machine and forced the minor, who was in his underwear and T-shirt, to go outside, where he was handcuffed to his mother. While Jerome McNeal, his son and wife were handcuffed on the rear porch, officers searched the apartment without permission. Donetta McNeal told the officers that this was illegal and that she would call the Office of Professional Standards (OPS). Barroso responded, “You think we give a f**k about OPS? Keep talking and we’ll lock your f**king ass up.” Jerome McNeal was transported to a police station and charged with a felony offense of unlawful use of a weapon.

Rufus was near 57th Street and South May Street when officers ordered her to stop, searched her and verbally threatened her. The officers filed police reports accusing Rufus of having a shotgun at the time of the search. A judge later acquitted Rufus of the gun charge.

Riney was heading to see his grandchildren when he stopped to ask a man on the corner for a light for his cigarette. Officers Dieball and Reykjalin pulled up and stopped Riney, telling him that they needed to check to see if he had any outstanding warrants. The officers didn’t have a computer in the police car, so they forced Riney to go to a police station and made him strip and submit to a search. Dieball assured Riney that if they didn’t find anything, they would let him go. But when Riney was naked, the officers told him to bend over and open his buttocks, “called him a name” and handcuffed him to a ring in the wall. When the officers realized that there were no outstanding warrants for Riney, they tried to get him to provide information about anyone who had drugs or guns. Riney refused. The officers loudly insisted that the “deal was off the table” and charged him with possession of one bag of heroin. Riney spent four months in jail before the charges were dismissed.

Boston, an African- American man, was in the West Lawn neighborhood when he was arrested and charged for resisting and obstructing a peace officer. While the arrest took place, Boston did not resist officers. Later, the arresting officers—as well as those officers that stood by while the arrest took place—agreed to not report each other after making false reports to cover their misconduct. The officers involved do not have a history of falsifying reports. Boston believes that he was treated with unnecessary force and falsely charged due to racial discrimination.

Gay and a friend were in the Beverly neighborhood when they were approached by Officer Donohoe. Donohoe arrested Gay and her friend. Without any legal justification, the officer charged Gay with battery. Gay was later found not guilty.
Pitts was near 103rd Street and South Bell Street when Officer Donohoe grabbed and injured her while trying to arrest her. Pitts was charged with battery of a police officer but was later acquitted.

Officers Haritos and Park responded to a call of domestic battery at a residence. Once on the scene, officers were told the subject of the domestic battery was no longer home. Haritos and Park then verbally abused Orlando and Lee Edwards' mother, Mary Reed, and grandmother, Addie Reed. Mary told the officers to leave and called 911 for help. More officers entered the home. Orlando was tackled by officers, slammed on to the ground and hit in the legs with a blunt object. Haritos then placed Orlando in a headlock and punched him in the face. Orlando was handcuffed and led out of the home. On the way out, Haritos rammed Orlando's face into a door frame. Officers tackled Lee as he tried to leave through the home's rear exit. Haritos handcuffed him and said, "Nigger, I got you now." Haritos then slammed Lee's head and handcuffed wrists into the trunk of a police car while saying, "Hurts, nigger, don't it." An unknown officer told Mary , "If you don't like this, you shouldn't call 911." No one was given medical attention; instead they were taken to a police station. Several hours after their arrest, Edward and Lee were taken to a hospital for medical treatment after their lawyer arrived at the police station. Officers charged Edward and Lee with aggravated assault of police and other resisting arrest charges. These charges were later dismissed.
Comer was arrested by Officer Gonzalez without lawful basis and held in custody at the Cook County Jail for about 75 days.

McCluster was driving his car on South Lake Shore Drive when Officer Parker pulled him over and ordered McCluster to the rear of the car. Parker had McCluster take sobriety tests, all of which he passed. Despite any evidence of impairment, Parker arrested McCluster on suspicion of driving under the influence. McCluster was later found not guilty.

J.T., a minor, was at his home in Posen, Ill., when officers came to conduct a search warrant for his father. In the midst of their search, the officers shot J.T. and also shot and killed both of his pet dogs.
Howard was walking and stopped to speak with a friend when officers stopped, searched and arrested him without a warrant. He was charged with drug possession but the charges were later dismissed.

Nelson was sitting in his van at a gas station when Officers Lis, Novotny, Ruzak and Wilson arrived and pulled their guns out, aiming them at Nelson’s face. The officers told him to get out of his car and threatened to “blast [his] ass.” Nelson exited the vehicle, and the officers twisted his arms, handcuffed him and searched the van without his consent. When the officers saw campaign signs in the back of the car, they realized he was a political candidate and said, “We suggest you get out.” The officers told Nelson to drive to a gas station up the road, wait for a few minutes and leave. When Nelson called the Chicago Police Department to report the abuse, he asked that the images taken by the nearby blue light surveillance cameras be preserved. The images were not preserved.

﻿Giles was driving his cousin, Oscar Salgado, and a friend when he saw a beige Chevrolet make a sharp U-turn and begin following his car. Officer Johnson, who was driving the unmarked car, continued to pursue Giles’ car at high speed and eventually placed a rotating light on the roof of his car. Giles feared that the driver of the car chasing him was not really a police officer, and that he and his friends would be robbed or attacked if he stopped. 
Johnson continued to chase Giles at a dangerously high speed that led to a car accident, killing Salgado and seriously injuring Giles. Several police officers arrived at the scene and, despite Giles’ injuries, threw him to the ground, put him in handcuffs and kneed him in the back. When Giles tried to explain he was injured and in pain, an officer responded, “I’m going to ship your ass back to Mexico.” He also threatened to “plant something” on Giles.
 Another officer slammed Giles’ head onto the sidewalk. Later, Giles was taken to a hospital, where he was diagnosed with a fractured spinal cord. He also suffered bruising on his right shoulder, injuries to the back of his head and knees, and a deep, open wound on his left leg.

Blanchard was walking when Officers Loduca and Hernandez pulled up next to him. They exited their squad car, pointed their weapons at Blanchard's head and shouted profanities at him. The officers had not identified themselves as police officers and Blanchard, afraid for his life, began to run. Once officers caught up to him, near North Ashland Avenue and West Blackhawk Street, they put Blanchard onto the ground. Officer Rodriguez jumped on his back and Officer Agosto handcuffed him and started searching him. Officer Agosto found Blanchard's identification car and pressed it against his face and said, "South side s**t never s***s in [their] own backyard." An unidentified officer kicked Blanchard's forehead while he was still handcuffed on the ground and after the officers they took him to a police vehicle, another officer punched and choked him.

Asad was walking near 99th Street and Paxton Ave. when Officers Morgan, Sanchez and Plebanski stopped him and began to beat him. As a result of the beating, Asad suffered a black eye, swollen lip and lacerations on his face. He was taken to a hospital to be treated for his injuries and then falsely charged with two counts of aggravated assault to a peace officer. He was found not guilty in February 2009.

Carter, who was 69 at the time, was involved in a traffic accident and taken to a hospital for treatment. When he was released to officers, Carter told them he could not walk and needed medical attention. But officers handcuffed Carter, threw him into a paddy wagon, took him to a police station and threw him into a cell without letting him see a doctor. Officers left Carter lying on the concrete floor of the cell and threatened to sodomize him if he didn’t get up to be fingerprinted and processed. The next day, Carter was taken back to the hospital and then to another hospital, where he was diagnosed with extensive spinal fractures and a rotator cuff injury--injuries that he did not have after the accident.

Horan was at home when Officers Burke and Smith and Sergeant Zodo entered his home after midnight without a warrant. The officers used unnecessary force against Horan, who suffered physical injuries from the incident.

﻿Officer Hoyas prepared a search warrant for a second-floor unit of an apartment building. The building listed had two units on the second floor: one in the front, one in the rear.
 Two days later, at 8 a.m., several officers executed the warrant and searched the front apartment without finding any weapons, narcotics or other contraband. As the officers were leaving the building, they saw a door that led to the rear apartment. With their guns drawn, the officers forced their way into the second-floor rear apartment where Chilcutt and Otero were sleeping. Without a warrant, the officers searched Chilcutt and Otero’s apartment and found one gram of marijuana, worth about $5. 
The officers charged Otero with illegal possession of cannabis. About two months later, the charges against Otero were dismissed.

In January 2008, someone sprayed mace at three people near the intersection of West Belmont Avenue and North Harlem Avenue. A sergeant with the Melrose Park Police Department informed Officers Lieblick and Loquercio and Detective Wronkowski that Muczynski was the perpetrator of the mace attack, even though he knew this was false. The Chicago officers also knew this was false, but they intimidated and coerced the three individuals who were maced to fabricate statements against Muczynski. Because of these statements, the officers arrested Muczynski and charged him with three counts of battery. The charges were later dismissed after the three witnesses asked the court to withdraw the charges.

Berry was driving along South Lake Shore Drive when Officer Parker pulled him over. Although Berry was not committing any crimes, Parker ordered him to the rear of the vehicle and performed field sobriety tests, which Berry passed. Despite the lack of evidence, Parker arrested Berry on suspicion of driving under the influence.

Garcia was driving home from work when Officer Hertko pulled him over without justification. Officers then filed false misdemeanor charges against Garcia. The charges against him were later dismissed.

﻿Davis was on his front porch when one or more officers in plainclothes ordered Davis to get inside. One of the officers, who was standing on the porch of the home next door, asked Davis, “What your b***h ass doing out here?” The officers did not identify themselves as police, and one or more drew their weapons and aimed them at Davis. The officers then jumped over the railing that separated the two porches and threw Davis face down to the ground. 
One or more of the officers twisted Davis’ leg, kicked him in the face and hit him in the back multiple times. The officers handcuffed Davis and arrested him without a warrant or probable cause. They took Davis to a nearby police station and charged him with three counts of aggravated assault to a police officer. 
Following his release from custody, Davis sought medical treatment at a hospital. All charges against him were later dismissed.

Hunter was at a store in the North Lawndale neighborhood when Officers Garza and Ormond walked in and grabbed him. Officer Hood was in the doorway and assisted with the stop. Mayer and Michon arrived at the scene and helped search and arrest Hunter without reason to believe that he had committed a crime. Ormond, Garza and Hood filed felony drug charges against Hunter. He was in jail for three weeks as a result of these charges, which were later dismissed.

Ortiz was in his home on the second floor of a building in the Portage Park neighborhood when Officer Edwards entered his residence. The officer had a search warrant for the building's basement, but not for Ortiz's residence. Without any legal justification or probable cause, Edwards threw him onto a glass table. Ortiz was arrested and charged with criminal complaints.

Brown was leaving a friend’s apartment as police were responding to a report of a burglary-in-progress at a storefront in the same building. Officer Schwandt arrested Brown, planted a doorknob on him and falsely reported that he saw tools in his hand. Brown was convicted of burglary based on police testimony and was sentenced to six years in prison. Schwandt later retracted the statement, and Officer Yi, who also responded to the burglary-in-process call, falsely testified that he inventoried stolen doorknobs found on Brown. Nearly five years later, Brown’s conviction was reversed.

﻿Collette Stamps was at home with her boyfriend, Walter Hopkins; her 13-year-old daughter N.S.; 7-year-old son A.S., and 6-year-old daughter J.L. The family lived on the third floor of a 12-unit building, with three other units on their floor. The previous day, an informant told Officer Honda a man was dealing drugs from a third-floor unit in the Stamps’ building. The family was eating dinner when they heard two loud bangs at their front door. Before they could respond, several plainclothes police officers broke down the door and stormed inside the apartment with their guns drawn. The officers screamed obscenities at the family and told them to get on the ground. Hopkins obeyed, and an officer handcuffed him and put a gun to his head. Collette Stamps and her children ran to a nearby bedroom. After some time, the officers informed the family they had raided the wrong apartment and apologized.

﻿Carradine was at a friend’s home when Officers Cortes and Martin detained, handcuffed and unlawfully searched her. The officers took Carradine to a police station, where they filed reports charging Carradine with drug possession. One month later, all criminal charges against Carradine were dismissed.

Wilson was driving near West Madison Street and North Lorel Avenue when officers pulled him over for a broken headlight. During the traffic stop, Wilson reached to make a call on his cellphone. At some point, one of the officers shouted "gun,” falsely indicating to the other officers that Wilson had a gun, even though he was unarmed. Officers Santiago, Vidljinevic and Deleon collectively fired 24 shots at Wilson, 18 of which struck his body, killing him. The officers planted a gun outside Wilson’s car and conspired to create a false account of the incident to explain how the gun ended up outside of the car, claiming that Santiago knocked the gun out of Wilson’s hand using his flashlight.

﻿Marcus Rodriguez was at Stallworth’s house watching a football game when he received a call saying police were raiding the apartment he shared with his mother, Maritza Malave. Marcus Rodriguez rushed home, where an officer asked for his identification before letting him check on Malave and his 14-year-old sister V.R. Marcus asked Lieutenant Proebski for a search warrant, but Proebski told him to go away. When Marcus Rodriguez repeated the question, Proebski pushed him out of the home while another officer grabbed Marcus’ long hair and pulled him down on the stairs outside the home. Officer Berg jumped on Marcus Rodriguez’s back, pushed his head against the ground and handcuffed him. Officers Rooney and McGarry hit Marcus Rodriguez multiple times in the face and ribs. One of the officers also kicked Marcus Rodriguez in the groin. When another officer pulled out a Taser, Stallworth grabbed it. The officers then arrested Stallworth. Berg picked up Marcus Rodriguez and dropped him onto the cement face-first, chipping Marcus Rodriguez’s tooth. The officers put Marcus Rodriguez in a squad car along with his cousin Alex Garcia, Stallworth, V.R. and his upstairs neighbor, Brown. At the police station, Berg repeatedly pretended to lock up V.R. in a cell, taunting Marcus Rodriguez by saying, “How do you like THAT, tough guy?” Marcus Rodriguez was charged with aggravated assault of an officer; everyone else was charged with resisting arrest. V.R. was charged as a juvenile. All of the charges were eventually dismissed except those against Marcus Rodriguez. The police released him at 1:30 a.m., and he went to a hospital where he had a CAT scan and an X-ray for his injuries. As a result, Marcus Rodriguez missed three days of work and was unable to lift anything heavy for several weeks after the incident. The plaintiffs later learned the police had Marcus Rodriguez’s father, who does not live at the family’s apartment, under surveillance. The police continued to harass the family, and Brown moved out of the building because of the frequent harassment.

Ragland was in the Logan Square neighborhood when Palm, Younan, Haleas and unknown officers arrested him and took him to a police station, where he was booked, processed and charged with assault. At the police station, Officer Ortiz shot Ragland with a Taser. Palm, Younan, Haleas, Moriarty and unknown officers did not intervene. Ragland was immediately taken to the hospital. The officers filed an additional charge of battery against Ragland after this incident. A day after he was released from custody, Ragland was admitted to the hospital for chest pains. The charges against him were eventually dismissed.

Grooms was riding with his friend, Eddie Brantley, when police stopped the two and searched Grooms without a warrant. Officers Tencza and Turney searched the car several times, but initially found nothing. At that point, Brantley saw Tencza put an object in the back of the car, which belonged to his mother. Tencza then claimed he had found drugs there. Tencza and Wantuck then arrested Grooms and took him to the 9th District police station, where he was charged with drug possession. The drug charges against Grooms were dismissed after a lab analysis showed that the substance found in the car was not drugs.

Over a 14-month period that began in October 2007, Mark Geinosky received 24 false parking tickets in the mail. At the time, he had agreed to let his estranged wife, Sharon Geinosky, use the car, which was still registered in his name. Sharon Geinosky insisted that she didn’t commit any traffic or parking violations, and in fact, the tickets were not left on the car. Mark Geinosky contested the tickets several times and also contacted the Independent Police Review Authority, the Internal Affairs Division, and the Chicago Tribune’s “Problem Solver,” to resolve the matter. Eventually Mark sold the car and transferred the title to a new owner, but continued to receive false tickets.

Blackwell was in front of his relative’s West Garfield Park home in Ford’s parked car when officers drove up in a squad car. The officers ordered Blackwell, who was a passenger, to exit the car, and then they searched him. They found no contraband on him. Ford, who owned and had been driving the car, had entered the house to use the bathroom before the officers arrived. The officers took Blackwell’s cellphone and started punching buttons on the phone, while asking him to find them some guns. Blackwell was seized and placed in handcuffs while they searched Ford’s car without a warrant or without permission. Although the officers found no contraband inside, they arrested Blackwell and seized the car. At the police station, officers showed Blackwell bags of a controlled substance. Blackwell protested that he did not have drugs on him, and the officers replied, “You do now.” Blackwell was booked and charged with felony drugs charges and traffic charges. He was incarcerated for two months. Ford never received her car or the personal property that had been inside the car at the time of Blackwell’s arrest. The charges against Blackwell were dismissed.

In 2008, Dean and Lopez were driving in the Lakeview neighborhood when Officer Fiorito stopped them and arrested them for DUI. Despite performing the Standardized Field Performance Test, and knowing that they were not driving under the influence, Officer Fiorito charged them with false DUI charges. The officer created false reports and provided false testimony in court. The arrest of Dean and Lopez were part of a series of other improper arrests by Officer Fiorito, done with the purpose of accumulating overtime pay for court appearances. Officer Fiorito is a midnight officer and is paid overtime for every court appearance that is not scheduled during his regular shift. Because all court appearances never occurred while he was on overnight duty, Officer Fiorito was guaranteed overtime pay. Due to the high volume of his cases, the City added “key dates” to his court schedule, happening once a month where the bulk of his cases would be scheduled on those days. However, Fiorito was present in court nearly every day. All of his police reports were similar in content, always claiming that every driver in every DUI arrest would “fail to stay in lanes,” “swerve, speed, drive without headlights,” “almost strike parked cars,” and “fail to wear seatbelts.” Officer Fiorito did this for several years until 2009 when a representative of the Cook County State’s Attorney said that Officer Fiorito’s credibility was being questioned, and therefore, he could no longer be used as witness for the prosecution. The charges against Dean and Lopez were eventually dismissed.

Between 2007 and 2009, Johnson was falsely charged with possession of illicit drugs by Officer Beckman on two occasions. The first incident occurred in September 2007 as Johnson was walking in the East Garfield Park neighborhood. Beckman strip-searched Johnson, pulling down his pants and underwear, while Officer Granville held him. Beckham falsely claimed to find six bags of cocaine on Johnson. The officer arrested Johnson and charged him with possession of cocaine. Johnson spent nearly five months in Cook County Jail until he was granted a motion to quash the arrest and suppress evidence. The second incident took place in March 2009. Beckman again approached, stopped and arrested Earl, accusing him of holding five bags of heroin. He spent more than two months in jail and lost his employment as a result. The case was later dismissed.

Hardiman was arrested at an apartment building on suspicion of criminal trespass and taken to a police station. There, his right hand was chained to a wall and he lay on a concrete bench. After refusing to give his name and address to two officers, Officer Jimenez entered the room to question Hardiman. When Hardiman remained silent, Jimenez kicked Hardiman’s right side, sending Hardiman to the ground. Jimenez punched Hardiman in the left eye before telling two other detainees they should talk to Hardiman or he’d “get more of what [he] just got.” 
Another officer called the Office of Professional Standards, and a representative came and took Hardiman to a hospital. Hardiman received an X-ray and treatment for his eye. Hardiman’s case was dismissed with leave to reinstate should new evidence arise.

Jesus Razo and and Evelyn Cortez were at a grocery store when a car sideswiped their vehicle and drove away. Enrique Oliva, who had been with the two, followed the car in his own vehicle, while Jesus Razo and Cortez followed on foot. At 26th Street and Drake Avenue, police stopped the car that had been involved in the hit-and-run. But officers handcuffed Oliva when he showed up to the scene, and shoved Jesus and Evelyn when they arrived and tried to explain what had happened. Some of the officers beat and arrested Jesus. Evelyn called Jesus' family and told them what was happening. But when a relative, Ernesto Razo, showed up and and tried to explain to police that they had made a mistake, officers beat him and arrested him as well. Several hours later, Oliva was released. Jesus was charged with aggravated battery to a police officer. Ernesto was charged with obstructing an officer and battery. Both had to be taken to the hospital for their injuries, which included severe bruises, abrasions and cuts. Charges against both were later dismissed.

A few minutes after Parra and a friend arrived at a car repair shop at 77th and South Claremont Avenue, officers burst into the shop with their guns drawn. Officers ordered Parra to lie down on the ground, handcuffed him and put a foot on Parra’s face. One officer found a handgun in Parra’s waistband, then called him a “stupid Mexican m*********ker,” pointed the gun at his face, hit him several times in the face and head --causing Parra’s head to hit the concrete floor-- and kicked his lower body. The beating caused Parra’s right eye and nose to bleed, his eye to swell shut, and broke his nose; he also suffered facial cuts and strained neck ligaments. Other officers watched the beating and laughed as Parra lay bleeding on the ground.

Torres was sitting in his open garage with a friend, drinking and waiting for the friend's brother to arrive, when they heard gunshots from down the block. His friend stepped out of the garage to see what happened and if his brother was approaching, when Officers Hayes and Dowling, responding to the gunshots, drove up. The officers approached Torres, who was still sitting in his garage, and searched him. They didn't find anything. Then they searched Torres’ garage and found a handgun that he lawfully owned in a box in the corner of the garage. They arrested Torres and charged him with unlawful use of a weapon possession of a firearm while not on his property. They falsified reports to justify the arrest. Torres was found not guilty of all charges at trial after more than three years.

Reed was attacked by Officers Sarabia and Wrigley as they attempted to arrest him. Sarabia jumped on Reed’s back, forcing him to the ground and putting him in a chokehold and headlock while other officers handcuffed him with his hands behind his back. Sarabia kneed Reed in the genitals and placed him in the squad car, stating, “I finally got you now.” When Sarabia was walking back to the other officers, Reed opened the squad car’s door and began running westbound, unnoticed by the officers. Still handcuffed, he hid in an abandoned vehicle in a vacant lot. Sarabia and Wrigley found him and told him to get out of the car and lay on the ground. Reed complied. Sarabia discharged a chemcial spray on Reed’s face and ears while Reed remained handcuffed and on the ground. The officer struck Reed in the face with a closed fist and sprayed the chemical on Reed's skin beneath his underpants. At the same time, Wrigley repeatedly struck Reed on the back of his legs with a police baton as he stood on Reed’s back. Both officers dragged him to a police wagon and deliberately let Reed, who was blinded by the chemical spray, fall and hit his head on a gate. Once inside the police wagon, Reed was allowed to take off his clothes, which were filled with chemical spray. He was allowed to shower at the station and was given a paper suit that did not fit past his waist.

Patten was handcuffed and searched by Officer Bernichio without any legal justification. The officers then filed felony weapons charges against him. On Sept. 12, 2007, Bernichio committed perjury in front of a Cook County Grand Jury to cover up Patten's unlawful arrest. Bernichio was later charged with nine counts of perjury and official misconduct on April 16, 2008 in a different criminal case involving the unlawful arrest of someone else. The charges against Patten were later dismissed.

Thomas had just left a party with some friends and was standing with the friends outside a parked car in a tow zone. One of Thomas’ friends was sitting in the car’s backseat when Officer Zala arrived and ordered the friend out of the car, claiming that he was drunk. Thomas politely asked Zala what the problem was and explained that his friend was not driving the car. Thomas then asked Zala if they could pay the $160 fine to avoid the car being towed. 
Zala said no, and began cursing and yelling at Thomas and his friends. Zala rushed at Thomas and pushed him in the chest. Thomas stumbled onto the sidewalk and began walking away from the scene with his friends. Zala ran up to Thomas, pushed him facedown on the ground and handcuffed him. Zala repeatedly punched Thomas on the right side of his face, and put Thomas in a paddy wagon. Because of the beating, Thomas had to receive medical care at a hospital for cuts, bruising and swelling on his face and bruises on his shoulder. 
The criminal charges against Thomas were later dropped.

Britton was a detainee at a police station, where he was being photographed and fingerprinted. Without justification or provocation, Officer Jones punched and kicked Britton. As a result of this assault, Britton suffered severe and permanent injuries.

Pearce was detained and taken into police custody while he was in the Clearing neighborhood. He was charged with reckless conduct even though officers failed to witness misconduct. While at the station, officers threatened him with lockup if he did not identify a marijuana source. After multiple threats, Pearce identified an individual known as “Hitman”. Pearce had not purchased any drugs from “Hitman” in four months and identified a gang way between two houses in the Ashburn neighborhood as the last place of purchase. An officer submitted a complaint for search warrant naming Rudy Cantu (a.k.a. “Hitman”). In the search warrant, the officer falsely stated that a cooperative individual had approached them with the information after having bought drugs from “Hitman” approximately 30 times over the past three months at a residence on 84th Place. The officer did not inform the State’s Attorney’s Office that Pearce, the cooperative individual, was detained. The next day, the officer sent a second complaint for search warrant. This warrant claimed that Cantu lived in a residence on 78th Place. The officer made false claims that Pearce had purchased drugs from Cantu at this location more than 30 times in the last three months. Pearce was taken to a lock-up and presented before a judge in order to get the warrant approved. Officers told Pearce that if he wanted to get out, he needed to tell the judge that everything on the warrant was true. He was never given the exact details of the warrant’s content. The judge approved the warrant and Pearce was taken back to lockup. Officers proceeded to execute a search warrant of the residence on 78th Place. Livingstone, 56, and her mother, Manny, 83, had lived at this location for over 30 years. Without showing a warrant, the officers detained both women inside the house for two hours even though Livingstone told the officers that her son was a Chicago Police detective. She proceeded to call her son, who later arrived at the scene. The search was called off.

Harrison was standing near the intersection of Roosevelt Road and Sacramento Avenue when Officers Fitzgerald and McGovern drove up in their squad car. When Harrison began to run, Fitzgerald chased him and shot and killed Harrison.

Collins was at a city bus station, where security guards and police beat him. Collins did not commit any crimes or use a weapon warranting the excessive use of force. He suffered injuries to his head, body and limbs. Collins’ case was later settled.

Johnson was in his bedroom at his mother's house when someone called 911 asking for him to be removed from the home. When the officers arrived, Johnson was naked and non-combative. He asked them if he could use the bathroom; they agreed, and handcuffed him. While Johnson was sitting on the toilet, naked and handcuffed, Sgt. Bednarek, without provocation, fired a Taser at him twice. Bednarek then sprayed Johnson with two canisters of pepper spray and fired his Taser several more times. He also applied electrical shocks directly to Johnson's body. Officer Lenski then sprayed Johnson again. A number of officers forcibly removed Johnson from the bathroom and threw him on the dining-room floor, where Officer Coffey, who weighed more than 400 pounds, placed his knee on Johnson's shoulder and pushed his body weight into Johnson's forehead and face. Officers hog-tied Johnson and carried him by his ankles and wrists out of the house and threw him in the back of a police wagon. When paramedics arrived, Bednarek told them to treat the officers, who were overcome by the pepper spray, and not to provide care to Johnson. At some point, Johnson became unresponsive. He later died.

Hughes was driving Stagger-Hughes’ vehicle in the Belmont Cragin neighborhood when Officers Iza and Uczen, who were in plainclothes in an unmarked police car, pulled over the vehicle. They immediately ordered Hughes out of the vehicle, handcuffed him and placed him in the back of the unmarked car. One of the officers searched the vehicle and found an over-the-counter vitamin in Stagger-Hughes’ lunch bag. The vehicle was seized and impounded without justification. Hughes was arrested and taken to the police station, where he was held for more than 24 hours. He was taken to Cook County Jail for two days, then placed under house arrest. The vitamin capsules tested negative for illegal substances, but officers failed to inform the State’s Attorney's Office or Hughes’ attorney. As a result, Hughes spent additional weeks on house arrest. The charges against him were dismissed after 22 days in custody, and Stagger-Hughes’ car was released.

Rios was in front of his McKinley Park home with his two minor children when Officers Kelly and Weber confronted him. Without any cause, the officers grabbed Rios, slammed him into a wall, threw him onto the concrete sidewalk and kicked him while he was handcuffed. The officers pointed a gun at Rios, who was bleeding from his injuries. His two minor children witnessed the assault. At the police station, the officers continued to kick Rios. He was charged with battery on a police officer, resisting arrest and drinking on the public way. The charges were later dismissed.

On July 22, 2007, Bass was at an athletic event in the South Loop when police arrived and broke up the event. Bass expressed her opinion that the officers’ actions were unfair and that they would not do the same thing to a group of whites. Three days later, officers arrested Bass in front of her minor children, searched her and took her into custody. Due to the events that took place three days before, officers charged her with inciting a riot or reckless conduct. Bass was booked, processed, charged and jailed. While at the police station, and while she was handcuffed to a wall, she was repeatedly insulted by the officers. During this time, she also became sick. The charges were later dropped.

Reese was at East 91st Street and South Prairie Avenue when Officer Pettis approached him. Reese did not pose any threat or danger, but Pettis shot him in his hip and arm. In retaliation for filing the lawsuit against Pettis, police officers have harassed and intimidated Reese.

Flores, who had bipolar disorder, was standing on the roof of a house in Cicero when officers arrived to carry out an arrest warrant against him. When the officers arrived, Flores told them he was suicidal and was planning to harm himself. Family members also told the officers about his condition. Paramedics arrived at the scene to assist and Flores eventually surrendered to CPD officials, who transported him to the 11th District police station. During his detention, Flores was not taken to a hospital or mental health facility and the appropriate CPD personnel or individuals trained to address his mental health condition were not notified. Instead, he was placed in a holding cell that contained objects that could be used to end his life. Flores commited suicide while in lock-up.

On February 17, 2007, Wiek was inside his home when Officers Keane, Reyes and Hajdu entered without a search warrant and without permission. He was placed under arrest and taken to the police station. Officers held him overnight in order to build a case against him and to use him for a line up the following morning. A City of Chicago policy allowed officers to hold arrestees overnight to be exhibited in line-ups. The following day, Wiek was part of a line-up and was set-up to be identified by a victim of a crime. As a result, he was charged with a criminal offense. He remained in custody until May of 2008 when he was found not guilty.

In June 2007, Carmen Cox was leaving his brother’s house on West Washington Street when Officers Anderson and Deady grabbed him, threw him to the ground, handcuffed him and punched, kicked, and beat him for several minutes. The officers then pulled Cox up, pushed him against a wall, and beat him for another two to three minutes. Another group of officers at the scene also began to beat Cox. As some of the officers started to put Cox into the squad car, another officer began driving and trapped Cox’s foot and leg underneath the car. Cox was taken to a hospital for treatment and was charged with aggravated battery and resisting arrest. When his mother, Lisa Cox, arrived at Loretto Hospital that evening to check on her son, officers Kane and Troutman refused to let her see him, then arrested her and charged her with trespassing. The charge against Lisa Cox was later dismissed. Carmen Cox later filed a complaint with the Office of Professional Standards. In September 2008, after the complaint was filed and over a year after Cox’s 2007 arrest, officers Siwek and Napoli filed a false police report alleging that they had tried to arrest Cox for unlawful use of a weapon. Months later, in January 2009, Carmen Cox was arrested again, based on the false September 2008 report.

Simmons was arrested for possession of a stolen motor vehicle. Officers Killackey, Viteri and Soto and Det. Kennedy beat Simmons and kicked his ribs while he was in their custody.Simmons was treated for his injuries and then taken back to a police station, where the officers again punched and kicked Simmons while he was handcuffed to a wall in an interrogation room because he wouldn't make a statement.
Officers Valkner and Gilger arrested Lee without a warrant. The officers handcuffed Lee and held her at the Area 5 police station, where they questioned her for approximately 78 hours.

Martinez was sitting in his parked car with the keys in his pocket when Officer Haleas pulled up next to him and ordered Martinez out of his car. Haleas searched Martinez, arrested him for driving under the influence and had Martinez’s car towed. Martinez had not been drinking alcohol or doing drugs.  
All charges against Martinez were later dismissed.

Jesse, Yalisha and Julio Olan were driving to a theme park when they encountered Officer Flores on a roadway. Flores displayed a fit of road rage and discharged his firearm in front of the Olan children. He arrested Jesse Olan without any probable cause or legal basis and caused him to be charged with a crime he knew Jesse Olan did not commit. The officer also illegally seized the Olans and their property. Flores, a trained boxer, also used physical force against Jesse Olan and the children. Jesse Olan was later found not guilty of the charge.

﻿Pizarro was in his apartment with his girlfriend, his family, and a couple of friends when he noticed a police officer in front of his building. Pizarro went to the window to see what was happening and the officer looked up at him and smiled. Officers then poured into the apartment and used a Taser on Pizarro multiple times on his chest and arms until he briefly blacked out. Pizarro’s mother attempted to stand and check on him and an officer kicked her in the head. She tried to look up and see the officer’s face but another officer called her a “little bitch” and told her, “You keep your face to the right.” One of the officers then shot Pizarro in the hand. When Pizarro’s frightened dog tried to leave the room other officers shot it to death. The officers claimed to have found drugs in the apartment and arrested most members of the family. Pizarro was transported to a hospital for treatment. Afterward, he was taken to the police station, where officers attempted to force a confession out of him. They also questioned his mother and younger sister. The police threatened to take away custody of Pizarro’s younger sister from his mother if Pizarro did not tell them where the drugs were. Pizarro’s case was settled almost four years later.

﻿Williams was riding his bike when Officers Rubald, Corcoran and Leck struck him in the head with a baton, causing him to bleed. The officers arrested Williams without any legal basis and continued to beat him on his face and body. The officers told Williams to “shut his black ass up” and referred to Williams, who is blind in one eye, as “Mr. Cataract.”  
The officers took Williams to a police station, where Williams was denied medical treatment even though the lockup keeper refused to jail Williams with his injuries. The officers, members of the now-defunct Special Operations Section, put Williams in jail anyway for possession of cocaine and resisting arrest. The case against Williams was eventually dismissed.

Lee and his nephew were driving in the South Shore neighborhood when Officers Riley, Duignan and Binfa pulled them over for a broken tail light. The officers ordered the two men out of the car, searched them and handcuffed them together, right wrist to left wrist. The officers told them to stand near the trunk of the vehicle while they searched the car. No contraband was found. Two additional officers, Turner and McInerney, arrived. Lee was freed from the handcuffs when one officer stated that he had found an expired search warrant from Memphis for Lee. After having the handcuffs removed and hearing that there was no valid warrant for his arrest, Lee thought he was free to leave, and began to walk back to the open passenger side door of his nephew’s car. As he did so, one of the officers jumped on top of him and knocked him across the front seats of the car. The officer knelt down on the front passenger seat and choked Lee by wrapping both of his hands around his throat. While Lee was being choked, another officer placed his gun into Lee’s mouth and said that he would shoot him. The officer removed the gun from his mouth, inserted a can of pepper spray and sprayed him in his mouth and face. Lee was ordered to roll out of the car onto the street on his belly, where his wrists were handcuffed behind his back. While handcuffed and lying on the street, Sgt. Rayl shot Lee with a Taser gun multiple times. Another officer attempted to snap Lee’s fingers one by one and succeeded in breaking one finger. After assaulting him, the officers dragged him into a police wagon. He was taken to the police station and questioned about a bag containing a white, powdery substance that was not found on him or in his nephew’s car. Lee was charged with possession of 15 or more grams of cocaine. He was in federal custody at the time he filed the lawsuit.

Condon was a resident at a drug and alcohol rehabilitation center in the West Loop when officials at the center requested that Condon report to the security office. Officers Lindahl and Grimm met him there, detained him, held him in a headlock and beat and battered him on the head and body. The officers took him to a police station for processing and to lockup at another police station. In lockup, Condon was handcuffed to a wall as Lindahl, Grimm and other officers beat and battered him and verbally provoked him. He was taken to the hospital, where he was examined and treated for his injuries. While Condon was at the hospital, agents with the Police Department's Internal Affairs interviewed him about the assault against him. He was charged with two counts of felony assault and one count of resisting arrest. Eventually, Condon was acquitted at trial.

J.M., 11, was playing with his sister, A.M., 13, and their friends at a school playground on the South Side. J.M. got in an argument with another boy and the boy left the playground. Later, the boy’s father, Detective Robert Smith, arrived at the playground with his son, who pointed at J.M. The father got out of his car and began to chase several kids around the playground before physically attacking J.M., yelling at him and telling him he was under arrest. When A.M. tried to help her brother, Robert Smith physically attacked her and told her she was under arrest too. A.M. broke free of Robert Smith and used a bystander’s phone to call her mother. When her mother arrived, she saw Robert Smith clutching her son. When she identified herself and asked Robert Smith to let J.M. go, he refused. Two female officers arrived at the playground, and Robert Smith released J.M., showed them his badge and told them to arrest J.M. Detective Gorman arrived, spoke privately with Robert Smith, and then handcuffed J.M. Sergeant Stacey Smith—Robert Smith’s wife—also arrived, as did Sergeant Evitt. Both sergeants told the other officers to arrest J.M. and A.M. The children were handcuffed and taken to a police station, where they stayed for eight hours. Their mother had to wait an hour until she could see her children, and the sergeants and detectives filed false reports against J.M. and A.M. The children were found not guilty.

Morales was driving his car in the Hermosa neighborhood when he was stopped by Officer Haleas who was on patrol. Morales was following all traffic laws at the time of him being stopped. After he stopped, the officer accused him of being drunk even though he had not been drinking. Morales only understood Spanish and does not speak English. Officer Haleas spoke to him in English and took him into custody. He charged Morales with disobeying a signal, failure to stay in the lanes and DUI. While the case was pending in court, it was made public that Officer Haleas had a history of not following proper procedures during DUI arrests. He would make false reports and falsely imprison citizens. All DUI cases involving Officer Haleas were dismissed, including the case for Morales. Officer Haleas was eventually disciplined. Due to his arrest, Morales had his driver’s license suspended and he was laid off from his job.

﻿Detectives Ferraro and Scott arrested Worthem on charges related to an alleged robbery. The arrest was based on manipulating the witness' identification, fabricating evidence and conducting a suggestive lineup. During the arrest, Ferraro and Scott slapped Worthem and roughed him up. Officer Nolan and Detectives Murphy, Scott and Ferraro then searched Worthem’s home, damaging Worthem’s furniture and other property. After they finished the search, the detectives left the doors open, which led to the loss of many of Worthem’s possessions. 
Worthem was found guilty and sentenced to 20 years in prison. He appealed the conviction and his case was sent back to court. Eventually, the charges were dropped.

Stapleton was driving a relative's car in the Chicago Lawn area when officers pulled him over. Officers Thornton, Thomas, Oksanen, Dougherty, Wright and Valeriano, members of the Special Operations Section, ordered Stapleton out of the car and handcuffed him. Officers then searched Stapleton and the car without legal justification. After an hour of searching, officers said they found some marijuana in the vehicle. Stapleton never saw the drugs the officers found. The car was impounded and Stapleton was taken to a police station where Thornton strip-searched him. At the station, Stapleton overheard officers say they had no grounds for his arrest. Oksanen suggested looking in the car again and the other officers made fun of him because they'd already searched it thoroughly. Three hours later, Officer Oksanen told Stapleton he found a gun in the car. Valeriano denied him use of the bathroom until he signed a false statement about the gun. Thornton threatened to knock Stapleton's teeth out if he did not sign the false statement. Stapleton was charged with felony gun and drug charges and issued a ticket for having a cracked rear view mirror on his relative's car. The mirror was not cracked and having a damaged mirror is not a violation of the law. The criminal charges were later dismissed, but Stapleton lost the impounded car when officers filed forfeiture proceedings for it and its contents.

﻿Harron and Lunn entered a bar and were removed by security. Officers Kurian and Muhhamad approached the men outside of the bar and accosted and restrained them. The pair were arrested even though they had not committed any crimes and did not resist the officers during the encounter. Kurian and Muhhamad filed reports indicating Harron resisted arrest and committed battery to one of the bar’s security guards.

Hudson was taken into custody by Officer Toczek and a detective with the United States Marshals Service. The officer and the detective were investigating the whereabouts of Hudson’s brother, a suspect in a homicide investigation, when she was searched and taken to a police station. At the police station,Toczek and detective sent other officers to search Hudson’s home. She was held at the police station for 13 hours and also interrogated. She was released later that evening. The following morning, Toczek and the detective arrived at her home with their weapons drawn. They proceeded to conduct a search of the home.

﻿Alston, who was unarmed, was approached by Officers Devries, Stoll and Peblanski on the street before Stoll shot him in the midsection.
To cover up the incident, the officers agreed to arrest Alston for disarming an officer and aggravated assault of an officer. The officers filed reports claiming Alston grabbed Devries’ weapon, even though DNA testing later revealed only Devries’ DNA on his gun. 
Unable to make bail, Alston was in jail for more than two years. He had multiple surgeries for the gunshot wound, and at one point had to wear a colostomy bag. He was released after a judge reduced his bail. Nearly a year later, a jury found Alston not guilty of both charges. As a result of his injury, Alston has incurred hundreds of thousands of dollars in medical bills.

Marcinczyk worked at Complete Care, Inc., a short-term care and hospice agency, and had a divorce pending with Bogdan Mazur. Mazur wanted to gain control of Marcinczyk's business and custody of his two children with her. To this end, Mazur planted a gun and drugs in his wife's vehicle and conspired with Officer Plewa to get Marcinczyk arrested. Plewa stopped Marcinczyk's vehicle and arrested her for weapon and drug felonies. Officers had no warrant to search her vehicle when she was pulled over; they relied on an anonymous "confidential source" that did not exist. Marcinczyk was held in Cook County Jail and then a federal detention center for 12 days. Marcinczyk's children were not allowed to visit her for at least 30 days. Police also impounded Marcinczyk's vehicle. She was later found not guilty of criminal charges. An investigation later conducted by the Cook County State's Attorney's office led to the arrest of Mazur and Plewa.

As they arrived for school at Lincoln Park High, Moore and another student were told to wait for Officer Jenkins. When Jenkins arrived, he took the two students to the “police room,” took Moore inside and told the other student to wait outside. Once inside the room, Jenkins grabbed Moore by the collar, shoved him against the wall, acted as if he was going to punch Moore in the face and told Moore “Do something. Go ahead, do it, I want you to.” When someone tried to enter the room, Jenkins let Moore go. Moore, afraid that Jenkins would harm him, called his mother, Sweezer, then went to his first-period class. Jenkins later came to Moore’s class and took him to another room, where students were being questioned about the theft of a teacher’s purse. While questioning Moore, Jenkins yelled at him, told him to “stop lying,” ordered everyone else in the room to leave and then hit Moore in the face with his fist three times. When Sweezer arrived at the school, she heard Moore screaming, ran into the room, and wedged herself between Jenkins and Moore to try and block Jenkins from hitting her son again. In response, Jenkins grabbed Sweezer and severely twisted her arm, even though Moore shouted that his mother had recently had a stroke. Sweezer and Moore were arrested and taken to a police station. Moore was later released without being charged. Sweezer was charged with obstruction of justice and resisting arrest, and Jenkins said to her “Since I can’t get your son, I got you.”

Benjamin Brown was in a store when Officers Everett and Pelayo took him into custody and walked him outside. Brown started to run, and the officers opened fire, shooting him several times. While he was on the ground, one of the officers shot him several more times, killing him.

Goins was driving on Central Park Avenue in the East Garfield Park neighborhood when Officers Philbin and Nikolakakis pulled him over. Although they had stopped Goins for a minor traffic violation, the officers arrested him on suspicion of driving under the influence and driving on a suspended license. Goins was transferred to a police station and placed in a cell. Daniels, a detention aide at the station, ordered Goins to step out of his cell. Daniels and Officers Rizzo and Mielcarz then assaulted Goins. During the attack, Officer Rizzo covered Goins' nose and mouth so he was unable to breathe. Goins was charged with aggravated battery and assault. The charges were dismissed seven years later.

In March 2007, Smyth was pulling into her garage in the Bucktown neighborhood when officers pulled their squad car in front of her. Officer Powe jumped out of the squad car and came up to Smyth’s window with his gun drawn. He ordered Smyth out of her car and handcuffed her. Powe and an unknown officer took Smyth up to her apartment, where they held her at gunpoint and locked her in a bathroom. While in the bathroom, Smyth cried and urinated on herself. After a few hours, two other officers arrived at the apartment. They all taped Smyth’s hands and legs to a chair using duct tape. Later that evening, Smyth’s boyfriend, Clark, arrived and the officers grabbed him as soon as he got out of the elevator and took him into the apartment at gunpoint. The officers duct-taped Clark’s mouth, eyes, hands and feet and held him for several hours. An officer forced Smyth at gunpoint to leave her apartment and drive him to Clark’s South Side apartment. On the way there, the officer requested backup. The officer and Smyth then drove back to her apartment. Smyth and Clark were kicked and beaten by the officers. The officers took Clark to another location while his eyes were still taped. The officers threw him down a set of stairs, beat him with a baseball bat and burned his chin using a lighter. During their detainment, Smyth’s and Clark’s homes were searched without warrants. Smyth and Clark were held for 14 and eight hours, respectively. Later that year, both were requested to come to the station for further questioning, and were held for 13 hours.

Ako was driving along the Chicago Skyway when Officer Parker pulled him over. Ako showed no signs of intoxication and was not committing any crimes. Parker arrested Ako without probable cause on suspicion of driving under the influence. Parker reported falsely that Ako had failed to stay in the lanes and was driving under the influence of alcohol. The charge cost Ako his driver’s license and his job as a taxi driver.

Officer Abbate Jr. was off-duty and having drinks at Jesse’s Shortstop Inn on West Belmont Avenue when he became so drunk, unruly and abusive that the bartender, Obrycka, refused to serve him any more alcohol. Abbate stepped behind the bar and attacked Obrycka, beating, kicking and punching her. Ababte left, and the police were called to the bar. The manager of the bar, Kolodziej, and a patron, Cepiaszuk, informed officers that Officer Abbate was a Chicago Police officer and that the assault had been recorded on video. A friend of Abbate’s who worked at Jesse’s told him about the tape. Abbate and his friend told Obrycka that if she declined to file a complaint, Abbate in exchange would pay for her medical bills, lost wages and other financial losses because of the beating. Obrycka refused. Abbate and other defendants then turned to threats, telling Obrycka, her manager, and the owner of Jesse’s that if they didn’t turn the videotape over to them or destroy it without showing it to anyone else, their lives--and the lives of other employees and even patrons of Jesse’s--would be in danger and they would be arrested on various trumped-up charges. Obrycka and her manager went to the police department’s Office of Professional Standards, but soon realized that the office was not properly investigating the attack. Representatives for Obrycka and the other plaintiffs gave the videotape of the beating to the media. Abbate was indicted in April 2007 on 14 counts of aggravated battery, official misconduct and conspiracy. Abbate was found guilty of aggravated battery, but acquitted of official misconduct, and sentenced to two years probation.

Officer Dailey was investigating the whereabouts of two cocaine dealers when he took part in creating two false complaints to obtain a search warrant of a home in the Austin neighborhood. The complaints claimed that on multiple occasions a confidential informant had purchased drugs from the two dealers at the home. Cooper, a 32-year-old decorated police officer, was at the residence with his two minor sons, his wife and his mother when officers forcibly entered the home looking for the two cocaine dealers. Assuming the home was being burglarized, Cooper drew his gun. In response, the officers also drew their guns. Cooper presented the officers with his badge and deed to the building, which he had owned for the past four years. Upon realizing that the warrant had the wrong home and that Cooper was a police officer, the officers decided to execute the search anyway. For 75 minutes, the officers forced the family to stay in one area of the home while the officers and two dogs searched all floors, including an unfinished basement. The officers left after finding no drugs or anyone living in the basement. The officers made reports stating that the Coopers had informed them that one of the cocaine dealers had previously lived in that residence. As a result of this, Cooper lost the trust of his co-workers in the department and has been harassed and intimidated on multiple occasions by off-duty officers waiting in front on his house.

Meakens was at the drive-through of a fast food restaurant at 75th and Stony Island when Sergeant Bechina, a member of the Special Operation Section, got him out of his vehicle and began interrogating him about the neighborhood. After asking where they could locate drugs and guns in the area, Officer Connolly entered Meakens’ vehicle, searched it, and uncovered $4,500 from rent receipts in a briefcase. They confiscated the money and placed Meakens in a squad car. Unable to provide the officers with an answer regarding drugs or guns, Meakens was transported to a police station and falsely charged with unlawful use of a weapon. He spent twenty-five days in jail, and was found not guilty at trial.

Officers obtained a search warrant for the basement and first-floor apartment of a home in Humboldt Park. Carter was a guest in a second-floor apartment in the building. The search warrant did not include the second floor of that residence. But as the officers executed their search of the basement and first floor, they also forced their way up to the second-floor apartment. The officers entered the apartment with their guns drawn. They seized, searched and handcuffed the residents of that second-floor apartment, including Carter. She was forced down to the first-floor apartment, where she was detained, searched again and held under arrest for a number of hours while officers continued to search the second-floor apartment.

Laverne, Robbin and Cordero Armstrong were at home when officers raided the home without legal cause. The family did not resist or make any attempt to leave, but the officers pointed their guns at them and damaged their residence looking for “guns and drugs.” Officers then filed false criminal charges against Robbin and took cash from the home. The charges against Robbin were later dropped but the money taken from tthe home was never returned.

Corder was loading laundry into his vehicle while it was parked in front of his home. Officers Turrise, Herman and White pulled up alongside him and asked what he was doing and what was in his vehicle. Then, without any legal justification, the officers searched and handcuffed Corder and searched his vehicle. The officers put Corder in their squad car before entering his yard to break into his locked garage. Corder was charged with felony drug charges. These charges were later dismissed.

Bloom was driving on Lake Shore Drive one night when Officer Parker pulled her over. Parker ordered Bloom to take field sobriety tests, which she completed. Bloom showed no signs of intoxication. Parker arrested Bloom anyway on suspicion of driving under the influence. Parker also stated in his report, without proof, that Bloom was speeding, driving negligently and under the influence of alcohol. A court later dismissed the criminal charges.

In December 2006, Booker was charged for the murder of a man earlier that year. The officers worked together to implicate Booker in a crime he did not commit to retaliate against his older brother, who had sued several police officers for excessive force, and to prevent Juan from testifying on behalf of his brother. Officers Brogan, Marley, Murray and Vovos manipulated, coached, threatened or coerced witnesses to implicate Booker as the murderer. The falsified statements were the only evidence linking Booker to the murder. He was charged with first-degree murder and aggravated unlawful use of a weapon. He was released from Cook County Jail in October 2010 when he was found not guilty of the charges.

Jonathan Hadnott was near West 56th Street and South Racine Avenue when Officers Kelly, Jarocki and Gilmore stopped him without reasonable suspicion or probable cause. The officers drove to a house that Jonathan owned and where Jessie Hadnott, Hunt and Betts lived, and searched the home without a warrant. The officers said they were looking for a gun, but they didn't find one. During the search, the plaintiffs were held against their will.

Williams was arrested in relation to a homicide investigation and was interrogated for more than 24 hours, during which he was repeatedly threatened by officers and ultimately coerced into giving a false confession. He was charged with the murder on the basis of the false confession. He was incarcerated in Cook County Jail for nearly three years until he eventually succeeded in having the false confession thrown out and the murder charges against him dropped.

Daniel Casares, who was a quadriplegic, was sitting in a car when several police officers struck him in the face and dragged him out of the car. They continued to hit and kick Daniel while he was on the ground. When Katrina Casares began yelling at the officers to stop, saying Daniel was paralyzed, the officers struck Katrina, who was pregnant.

Williams was driving in West Humboldt Park when he was pulled over by officers at gun point. He was questioned about gangs and shootings in the neighborhood, handcuffed and arrested. The officers proceeded to search Williams and the car he was driving without presenting a warrant and without permission. Williams was charged with possession of a gun and incarcerated. The car and its contents were impounded. All of Williams’ personal property was taken and kept as evidence. He was not able to regain this property or his car. He was found not guilty.

﻿Mayhew was allegedly involved in a robbery of Officer Gutierrez. After the alleged incident, Mayhew was in an apartment bathroom when police officers entered the apartment. Officer Dolan came into the bathroom with his gun drawn. Dolan ordered Mayhew to get on the floor and put his hands behind his head. Mayhew complied. 
Dolan kicked Mayhew in the head and handcuffed him, while another officer entered the bathroom and also kicked Mayhew in the head. Dolan stood Mayhew up and punched him in the face. Gutierrez entered the bathroom and asked Mayhew, “Remember me? Remember me, m***** f*****?” Gutierrez punched Mayhew so hard he fell to the floor. Dolan lifted Mayhew up by the throat and held him off the ground while the other officers punched Mayhew in the face and stomach. Dolan let Mayhew go, and Mayhew crumpled to the floor before Dolan struck Mayhew with the butt of a gun. Dolan then wiped off Mayhew’s bloody face with a towel. 
The officers took Mayhew to a police station, where they removed his bloody shirt and told him to put on a different one. The officers took Mayhew to a different police station, where they were ordered to get Mayhew medical treatment. They took Mayhew to a hospital, where he was given medication and his wounds were bandaged. Gutierrez and Dolan filed reports against Mayhew for armed robbery and battery. The next day Mayhew was taken to Cook County Jail. One month later, Mayhew filed a complaint with the Police Department’s Office of Professional Standards, but the office has not taken any action.

Delarosa was at home with her family when Officers Cerda and Surma arrived to assist animal control officers who were issuing citations related to two family dogs. While the officers were at the front door of the building talking to Delarosa's family members, her daughter arrived. The officers asked her for identification. She told them her name, that she lived there and that she didn't have any identification. They became verbally abusive and began to push her. Delarosa came to the front door and asked the officers why they were arguing with her daughter. Cerda turned and pushed Delarosa, who was 70 years old at the time, causing her to fall backwards and hit her head on the doorway. Family members asked the officers for medical attention for Delarosa, but they refused. Cerda threatened Delarosa with deportation if she complained about the incident. They then arrested the daughter for battery to a police officer and took her to a police station. Shortly after, Delarosa and other family members went to the station to ask about her daughter. While there, the officers arrested Delarosa and charged her with aggravated assault of a police officer. While in custody, Delarosa began to suffer from chest pain and was taken to a hospital, where she was admitted and underwent an invasive cardiac procedure. Shortly after she was released, she suffered a stroke and returned to the hospital, where part of her skull was removed to relieve the swelling. Six months later she was found not guilty of the assault charges.

Champion and his landlord, Dahlquist, verbally agreed that Champion would rent a room inside Dahlquist’s house, and that Champion would pay rent on a week-to-week basis. Dahlquist would provide a receipt after each week to track the payments received. For about seven months, Champion furnished his rented room with various pieces of furniture and lived there.
One day in September 2006, Champion heard someone trying to enter his locked room. He opened the door and found Officer Root, who said he was responding to a call from Dahlquist alleging that Champion was trespassing. Champion showed Root his rent receipts, signed by Dahlquist himself, along with other documents proving he lived there.
Nevertheless, Root removed Champion from his room and allowed Dahlquist to evict Champion. Root then filed a false criminal charge against Champion, and allowed Dahlquist to put Champion’s belongings in the yard, where they were soon stolen. Champion was later found not guilty of the charge.
Hernandez was held in an interrogation room for three days and not offered access to a bed, running water or toilet.

Swanigan was leaving a bank in the Irving Park neighborhood when Officers Trotter and Muehlfelder, without reasonable suspicion, stopped him as he walked toward his car. The officers told Swanigan that he looked like a robber and asked him if he was trying to rob the bank. They placed him in tightly bound handcuffs and searched him and his car without his permission. Additional officers arrived at the scene, including Sergeant Kaupert. The officers debated whether they had enough evidence to arrest Swanigan and agreed they did. The officers ordered his car to be impounded and towed. He was taken into custody and detained for more than 50 hours. During that time, he was confined to a small room, shackled to the wall, searched, fingerprinted and never told the reason for his arrest. The arrest report states that Swanigan was arrested for misdemeanors, which did not require the police to hold him for a bail hearing. Detectives Lynch and Mullane put a "hold" request on Swanigan for the purpose of trying to gather evidence against Swanigan for a robbery. During the 50 hours he was in custody, Swanigan was repeatedly moved from one police station to another, interrogated several times by Detectives Lynch and Mullane, denied food and drink, not allowed to sleep, and denied access to the bathroom, all in an attempt to coerce a false confession. Through his detention, Swanigan was ridiculed, threatened and taunted by unknown police officers. During these two days, Swanigan was denied access to an attorney, and his father, a retired police officer, was denied access to his son. Upon release, Swanigan was given two citations, for driving on a suspended license and driving without insurance. These false traffic charges were later dismissed. He received paperwork indicating that his car had been towed for possession of an unlawful firearm, even though the officers did not find a firearm in the car.

Kim Norton and other members of her family, including a minor, were sitting on her porch in the North Lawndale neighborhood when they were approached by an officer who had been searching for an individual. He was joined by two additional officers who declared that they needed to go into the home. One of the family members asked the officer if they had a search warrant, to which the officer replied “nigger, I don’t need a search warrant!”. The officers proceeded to attack the family on the porch and around the porch area. Kim, LaChoya and L. Norton, the minor, were arrested to cover up for the beatings. The charges against the family members were later dismissed.

Officers Vail, Fergus, Folino and McDermott arrested Zawadowicz at his home and held him in custody for more than 48 hours as they looked to build a case against him. Folino signed a complaint for preliminary examination, alleging that Zawadowicz had killed a man by battering him with a blunt object. The officer had no reason to believe that Zawadowicz had actually committed the crime. Three days after his arrest, Zawadowicz appeared before a judge, who ordered that he be held in custody. A month later, Zawadowicz was formally charged.

Cobige was arrested for a nonviolent criminal offense and taken to a police station. She was placed in a jail cell, where she began experiencing symptoms of a serious illness. Although Cobige repeatedly asked to receive medical care, the officers refused to take her to a hospital. 
The next morning, Officers Dimilanta and Czarniecki took Cobige to the courthouse for her bond hearing. Before leaving, Dimilanta told Cobige if she requested medical attention while at the courthouse, he would bring her back to the police station immediately. 
Soon after they arrived at the courthouse, a deputy sheriff noticed Cobige’s symptoms and asked her if she needed medical attention. Cobige replied yes, and the deputy sheriff told the officers Cobige would not be accepted for her bond hearing until she received medical treatment. Instead, the officers took Cobige back to the police station, where hours later she died on a cell floor.

Miller, an African-American male, was driving a Budget rental car as a professional livery driver when he was called to pick up a customer in Greater Grand Crossings. Miller had arrived 10 minutes early when the customer called to cancel the trip. As he was about to leave the pick-up location, a police car with flashing lights pulled up behind him. Without reason or cause, one of the officers ordered Miller to exit his vehicle, show his driver’s license and to empty his pockets. Miller complied with all of the requests. The officers proceeded to handcuff him and place him inside the police car. While detained inside the squad car, the officers searched the rental car without permission where they found his lunch and two pieces of aluminum foil containing salt and pepper. The officers informed Miller that he was being arrested for drug possession. One of the officers opened the foiled packages and sneezed. Even though they knew that the foiled packages only contained salt and pepper, the officers charged Miller with possession of a controlled substance.
